componenttext: I'm not going to talk about pricing in terms of anything going forward, but I will only talk about is what we've done in the past.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Give that perspective, at what point do your model show your volumes beginning to turn positive?
componenttext: Give that perspective, at what point do your model show your volumes beginning to turn positive?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, as you look at what we talked about for 2010, we'll have some carryover pricing, which is all we've announced at this in time. And we need to have volumes turn positive. Now, obviously the business is a bit unique in the first part of the year beca
componenttext: Terry, as you look at what we talked about for 2010, we'll have some carryover pricing, which is all we've announced at this in time. And we need to have volumes turn positive. Now, obviously the business is a bit unique in the first part of the year because we're still taking Valentines and Easter to new promoted price points. They were price protected last year, but we should start to see some volume gains as we get out through the year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess you know obviously, I was trying to get you to give us some sort of guidance on what kind of price volume algorithm you're contemplating on the top line, maybe that should wait for CAGNY as well, unless you'd care to share it now.
componenttext: I guess you know obviously, I was trying to get you to give us some sort of guidance on what kind of price volume algorithm you're contemplating on the top line, maybe that should wait for CAGNY as well, unless you'd care to share it now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'll pass.
componenttext: I think I'll pass.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jonathan Feeney with Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jonathan Feeney with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, just following up on Terry's question. I recognized your answer that Wrigley isn't exactly comparable in terms of relative advertising. But could you give us. I mean clearly you believe the relative advertising percentage you have right now isn't ad
componenttext: Dave, just following up on Terry's question. I recognized your answer that Wrigley isn't exactly comparable in terms of relative advertising. But could you give us. I mean clearly you believe the relative advertising percentage you have right now isn't adequate because you've he done such a good job raising it, is there a number or range in terms of relative sales that you get to in 2011 or 2012 where you say no more 30%, 35% type increases?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've been doing is you have to recognize what we've been doing as we've been going along, not only getting to what we think our threshold and/or sustaining levels on the brand. We've added more brands throughout. So we started back in '08. W
componenttext: I think what we've been doing is you have to recognize what we've been doing as we've been going along, not only getting to what we think our threshold and/or sustaining levels on the brand. We've added more brands throughout. So we started back in '08. We really focused first on Hershey's and the Reese's and then the latter part of '08. And certainly, in '09 on Kisses and getting to Kit Kat and Twizzlers through '09 and now in '10 adding in York, Mounds and Almond Joy. So we've been adding to the breadth, as well as getting those brands to what we think are sustaining levels of GRP. So I think we're now at the place where we have seven or eight core brands that we're promoting when you think about Hershey's Bliss and some of the work we're also doing on Ice Breakers. So we measure them all individually. And we will continue to keep that as a good investment as long as the ROI is positive. And we look at the ROI on that spending as well as the mix of the entire basket of promotion plus advertising. And we're making marginal spend decisions based on what is returning the best for our dollar. And as we continue to invest in brands like Reese's in the third year, a fairly heavy copy. We're still seeing very good returns on that. So we're watching it, we will continue to invest in it as long as it makes sense within the P&L framework, and is driving good top line return.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you think about your balance sheet right now, you're at least a turn and a half of EBITDA, below the industry averages for investment grade perfectly stable, perfectly comfortable company that frankly, aren't increasing their relative advertising spe
componenttext: When you think about your balance sheet right now, you're at least a turn and a half of EBITDA, below the industry averages for investment grade perfectly stable, perfectly comfortable company that frankly, aren't increasing their relative advertising spend at 50%, 35% clips. You have $100 million share repurchase. I mean you could be buying back 20% of this company if you wanted to stay in the middle of those ranges. Why aren't you more aggressive in share repurchase right now and do you plan to get more aggressive in the coming quarters?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the balance sheet, we ended the year quite pleased with our performance. As I mentioned, we have cash flow certainly at the upper ranges that we were able to generate in the past. We certainly value that credit, and as we talk with the Board,
componenttext: In terms of the balance sheet, we ended the year quite pleased with our performance. As I mentioned, we have cash flow certainly at the upper ranges that we were able to generate in the past. We certainly value that credit, and as we talk with the Board, we announced this morning a dividend increase. With respect to other forms of getting value back to the shareholder, certainly that's a Board level decision and a discussion which where we are today is the appropriate discussion to be having. So I would say your observation is one that is a similar discussion that we're having internally.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that somewhat of a reflection of your -- Dave, mentioned in his comments too, of your preference to keep some acquisition flexibility?
componenttext: Is that somewhat of a reflection of your -- Dave, mentioned in his comments too, of your preference to keep some acquisition flexibility?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we look at our capital structure in general, I think acquisition and flexibility has always played a role. We were certainly a bit more conservative towards the back half of '08 and the majority of '09, as the market uncertainty really that made sense
componenttext: As we look at our capital structure in general, I think acquisition and flexibility has always played a role. We were certainly a bit more conservative towards the back half of '08 and the majority of '09, as the market uncertainty really that made sense to us to preserve cash and to be more conservative with respect to what's going on the market. As we see that starting to thaw a bit, we're encouraged by our cash flow encouraged by the balance sheet that we do have. So I would say that M&A flexibility has always been part of our capital structure thinking and that's no different going forward.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to get a sort of what your guidance from an operating line perspective? And I just want to make sure I heard you right. If EPS is going to grow 6% to 8%, it sounds like pension and tax is going to provide 2% to 4% of that, and you got sale
componenttext: I'm just trying to get a sort of what your guidance from an operating line perspective? And I just want to make sure I heard you right. If EPS is going to grow 6% to 8%, it sounds like pension and tax is going to provide 2% to 4% of that, and you got sales up 3% to 5%. It sounds like operating profit growth is going to be flat to up 2%, do I have that right?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're expecting a continuation of gross margin expansion this year. We have a number of things that are still quite positive for us. I mentioned the Supply Chain Transformation, we have incremental savings in that regard. We have a very active productivit
componenttext: We're expecting a continuation of gross margin expansion this year. We have a number of things that are still quite positive for us. I mentioned the Supply Chain Transformation, we have incremental savings in that regard. We have a very active productivity program aside from that particular program. Now that we have -- and I think we've mentioned in the past, now that we have our manufacturing footprint in a more stable basis, we see productivity opportunities in sort of inputs going in and what's going out through that site. We're certainly expecting gross margin expansion below that. We already talked about 25% to 30% advertising inquiries. So my view on that is your observation on taxes is correct, and we do have a little bit of pension benefit. Interest, we think we'll be a little bit higher as that it was this year, as rates start to climb, and we think that will happen towards the back half of the year. So that's the only other component that we didn't talked about. We did give the range of $90 million to $100 million.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're going to have gross margin expansion. I recognized all the things that you just listed in there, but when we look at where cocoa, dairy and sugar, are those look like pretty profound increases and it sounds like you might have some nice hedges on i
componenttext: You're going to have gross margin expansion. I recognized all the things that you just listed in there, but when we look at where cocoa, dairy and sugar, are those look like pretty profound increases and it sounds like you might have some nice hedges on in terms of cocoa and sugar. I doubt you would want to elaborate and when those are going to come off, but can you remind us how you buy dairy and if we're looking at dairy prices when we should do about those flowing through your P&L?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our input cost in the current spot market are high. We have an active hedging program and so what we're talking about in terms of gross margin actually takes that into account as well as the productivity which we mentioned which is an offset to the input
componenttext: Our input cost in the current spot market are high. We have an active hedging program and so what we're talking about in terms of gross margin actually takes that into account as well as the productivity which we mentioned which is an offset to the input costs. There is no forward market per se for fluid dairy, which is an important component for us. Dairy prices have started to increase. They're certainly off the lows. We're not expecting them to reach the 2008 highs during this year, but we do think there continues to be volatility in commodities and we're watching it closely.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it a six-month lag? Is it a three-month lag from the spot dairy price? Is there any guidance you can give us on that?
componenttext: Is it a six-month lag? Is it a three-month lag from the spot dairy price? Is there any guidance you can give us on that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really give guidance on that.
componenttext: No, we don't really give guidance on that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Credit Suisse.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: People have already asked about the cadence of the volume for 2010. I guess I'm curious about the market share. You were down 40 basis points in the fourth quarter and you kind of described it related to the premium gift items. Can you tell us how much of
componenttext: People have already asked about the cadence of the volume for 2010. I guess I'm curious about the market share. You were down 40 basis points in the fourth quarter and you kind of described it related to the premium gift items. Can you tell us how much of the market share decline was specifically related to that? And then, do expect your share to improve quite a bit in the first half? Or should we expect market share to be kind of lagging in the first half and improving in the second?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what I would tell you on the market share is some of it is the premium, obviously, that we talked about this Cacao Reserve and Starbucks and some of the gifting . Remember also that we had some continued difficulties in the drug class of trade. So
componenttext: I think what I would tell you on the market share is some of it is the premium, obviously, that we talked about this Cacao Reserve and Starbucks and some of the gifting . Remember also that we had some continued difficulties in the drug class of trade. Some of that is premium and some of that was programming that we didn't lap very well. So I think those were the two big drivers. We had talked about those when we talked on the October call. So we were not surprised by the share loss in the fourth quarter. We had expected that we would lose share. As we go into 2010, we would expect that there'll be a little bit of continued pressure. Valentine's is again a holiday that's got a lot of premium in gifting in it. We may not perform quite as well there. We think we'll do better at Easter. We had a very good Easter last year and we're very pleased with our Easter programming this year. And then as the year goes on, obviously, the advertising and other factors kick in. So I think, Rob, that the first quarter may look a little bit more in measured channels like the fourth did, but I think for the full year 2010 we would expect market share to be something that looks similar. Full year last year, we were up 1/10 of a point so I would think about 2010 similarly 2009 for the full year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the competitive structure of pricing and promotion that you see out there. Are you seeing a rational environment? Are you seeing overly aggressive environment from your competitors? Or pretty much the same as you've always seen?
componenttext: When you look at the competitive structure of pricing and promotion that you see out there. Are you seeing a rational environment? Are you seeing overly aggressive environment from your competitors? Or pretty much the same as you've always seen?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's any way you can say it's pretty much like we've always seen because there was a significant change in pricing in the actual market last year. So we pretty much did what we said we were going to do and I think that from a consumer and
componenttext: I don't think there's any way you can say it's pretty much like we've always seen because there was a significant change in pricing in the actual market last year. So we pretty much did what we said we were going to do and I think that from a consumer and customer standpoint we saw the reactions that we expected, pretty much as expected.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But your competition raised price also?
componenttext: But your competition raised price also?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at your syndicated data, pricing in the entire category is higher.
componenttext: If you look at your syndicated data, pricing in the entire category is higher.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Investments.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Investments.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: One question about the quarter itself, could you tell us what the volume decline was in the quarter? I think you said it improved sequentially, but can you put a dimension around that?
componenttext: One question about the quarter itself, could you tell us what the volume decline was in the quarter? I think you said it improved sequentially, but can you put a dimension around that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I had mentioned that -- and I think we both mentioned that there was a sequential improvement -- and from mid-single digits to low single digits [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes, David, I had mentioned that -- and I think we both mentioned that there was a sequential improvement -- and from mid-single digits to low single digits [indiscernible].

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s base volume.
componenttext: That’s base volume.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Base volume.
componenttext: Base volume.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Base volume was down low single digits. And then if we put in -- what are the effects of the withdrawal of the Starbucks and Cacao Reserve products in the gifting products? Can you give us a volume impact?
componenttext: Base volume was down low single digits. And then if we put in -- what are the effects of the withdrawal of the Starbucks and Cacao Reserve products in the gifting products? Can you give us a volume impact?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about it in the quarter, pricing was roughly 10%; that reflects the list pricing through the seasons. We had a low-single-digit base volume decline. We had a seasonal shift also in the quarter of roughly a point or so, if you wil
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think about it in the quarter, pricing was roughly 10%; that reflects the list pricing through the seasons. We had a low-single-digit base volume decline. We had a seasonal shift also in the quarter of roughly a point or so, if you will, and discontinued items. So if you think about those, those are worth another couple of points. We had Valentine's and Easter that will ship in 2010 that shipped in the fourth quarter of the year ago. So when you think about it, it's roughly 10% or so pricing, some low-single-digit base volume declines and then also then the discontinued and seasonal shifts that kind of take you down where you were. So I think you're talking about roughly, I guess, David roughly say 7% or 8% on the pricing and then you take then take the volume buy-in, it's low single -- the volume base low single digits off and then the seasonal and the discontinued items is another couple of points. And that will get you to where we were.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: FX in the quarter.
componenttext: FX in the quarter.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the question on the use of cash. The only thing that wasn't mentioned by, I think it was Jonathan who asked the question, was it seems pretty obvious you're not buying stock in the quarter when you're contemplating the largest acquisition in
componenttext: Going back to the question on the use of cash. The only thing that wasn't mentioned by, I think it was Jonathan who asked the question, was it seems pretty obvious you're not buying stock in the quarter when you're contemplating the largest acquisition in your history. So I'm not surprised by the fact that we didn't see any share repurchase. You did acknowledge, I think, also I think you said $100 million of an existing authorization so that's at your discretion to execute whenever you see fit, and I would assume that would be forthcoming. But I suppose, Dave, what I really want to get after is just the balance sheet leverage is it's just fabulously low relative to the rest of the sector. Is there anything here that is just obvious that would want to detract from buying back the stock in your opinion?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get into the specifics of what we're going to do with respect to the balance sheet. I think Bert covered it very well. We increased our dividend today or yesterday, announced it today. I think that that, again, we had record cash flows fr
componenttext: I'm not going to get into the specifics of what we're going to do with respect to the balance sheet. I think Bert covered it very well. We increased our dividend today or yesterday, announced it today. I think that that, again, we had record cash flows from operations in 2009 and feel very good about that position. We do have the remaining share repurchases and as Bert said, and I said it as well, we're open to M&A. It's always been something that's factored into our equation. And we want to leave those levers available. It's certainly a Board level conversation and we have them continually. So I do want to get into anything more specific than that, other than that we're really happy with the cash flow performance of the business in '09, and very pleased that our balance sheet and our finance folks here have done a great job.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a date already set for the next Board meeting?
componenttext: Is there a date already set for the next Board meeting?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you tell us what the date is?
componenttext: Can you tell us what the date is?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd rather not. I don't want to get into talking about our internal governance. Actually our base is not only reset for 2010, they're set for 2011. So it's really kind of not relevant.
componenttext: I'd rather not. I don't want to get into talking about our internal governance. Actually our base is not only reset for 2010, they're set for 2011. So it's really kind of not relevant.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just big picture, I feel like after this whole discussion about whether or not you're going to get involved in the Cadbury discussions or not, people now question whether or not the company really has any kind of sustainable top line growth. The U.S. cate
componenttext: Just big picture, I feel like after this whole discussion about whether or not you're going to get involved in the Cadbury discussions or not, people now question whether or not the company really has any kind of sustainable top line growth. The U.S. category has done well for many years and I think people just need to hear you talk about why this is a good category in your expectations. You already made a couple comments about 2010 in the volume numbers to Terry. But again, Dave, why are you confident that the top line can grow? And I believe your guidance at 3% to 5%, it's very strong relative to what we hear from other companies with U.S. operations. Can you give people some color on this and explain your confidence?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think at CAGNY, we'll certainly talk about the category. And we continue to believe we are at an advantaged category. It's expandable, it's highly impulse oriented, it's a destination category because of the seasonal component of it. Certainly, three or
componenttext: I think at CAGNY, we'll certainly talk about the category. And we continue to believe we are at an advantaged category. It's expandable, it's highly impulse oriented, it's a destination category because of the seasonal component of it. Certainly, three or four times a year, the retailer has a desire to display the category. The category growth rate last year was this is in FDMxC was up 4.4%. We are looking at a long-term 3% to 4% growth rate category. And so when you think about our ability to be advantaged in that category and continue to grow with or ahead of that category growth rate, we feel very confident in our ability to do that. Our international business outside of the U.S. and Canada has been growing almost 20% compound over the last five years. So that's a nice additive. We're pleased with that growth in terms of where we are. Then you also look at the rest of the world and even despite Mars and Wrigley and Kraft and Cadbury, if Kraft and Cadbury closes, it's still a fragmented global category with opportunities out there to expand. And as Bert has already mentioned, we have a very strong balance sheet. So we feel good about where we're positioned. We feel that we did the right things in terms of taking a disciplined look at an asset that was available. It didn't work for us within the framework that we had established, but that doesn't mean that we're not highly confident in our business model.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to take a step back and look at your capacity utilization and whether there is a need to further shrink capacity. You commented that for this year, your volume declines were somewhat less than what you had forecast. But I'm wondering whether
componenttext: I was hoping to take a step back and look at your capacity utilization and whether there is a need to further shrink capacity. You commented that for this year, your volume declines were somewhat less than what you had forecast. But I'm wondering whether you take a broader step back to February 2007 when you unveiled the supply chain transformation program. Your capacity utilization, then, you were citing was in the low 60s and you want to get to about 85% by 2010. Are you still on track to do that? It would seem like the denominator or the production in place you've made good progress in reducing. But just wondering given the volume shift that we've seen whether you're still on track to get to that mid-80s kind of capacity utilization or whether further shrinkage in the business is needed?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll talk a little bit about that and recap some of those numbers at CAGNY. We are very, very pleased with the global supply chain transformation. Our operations folks have done a really fabulous job in what is a very complex and large project, t
componenttext: I think we'll talk a little bit about that and recap some of those numbers at CAGNY. We are very, very pleased with the global supply chain transformation. Our operations folks have done a really fabulous job in what is a very complex and large project, the largest one in the company's history. And it has gone very smoothly and without a hiccup. And you see the improvements in our balance sheet and working capital numbers  are very, very strong and that's largely part of the footprint and the improvements in the operations. We'll continue to look at our cost structure. We are now in a position in 2010 to look at how we supplied the new supply chain, if you will. So we really focused in '08 and '09 on the manufacturing footprint and that now leaves us with a number of opportunities as we go into 2010 and 2011 in terms of how to supply into it, in terms of procurement. And then also how to deliver out of it with transportation, warehousing and logistics improvements. And we're very focused on those improvements here in 2010 and '11, but we're always going to constantly look at capacity utilization in our network to make sure it's optimized. And I think we'll have a little bit more just to kind of share some of the numbers with you post global supply chain transformation at CAGNY.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the meantime, could you give us an estimate as to what you average in terms of capacity utilization for '09? I know that point-in-time estimates are for year end are skewed by seasonal factors...
componenttext: In the meantime, could you give us an estimate as to what you average in terms of capacity utilization for '09? I know that point-in-time estimates are for year end are skewed by seasonal factors...

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll cover that in a couple of weeks.
componenttext: I think we'll cover that in a couple of weeks.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard with Stanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard with Stanford Bernstein.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I ask about -- looking out into 2010, I think somebody else raised the question of premium strategy. I'm assuming that at some point, hopefully, the economy will start to recover. And I guess for 2009, the focus was very much on the non-premium part o
componenttext: Can I ask about -- looking out into 2010, I think somebody else raised the question of premium strategy. I'm assuming that at some point, hopefully, the economy will start to recover. And I guess for 2009, the focus was very much on the non-premium part of the market. Do you anticipate that you'll have a big push to get back into that premium segment? Or do you think you're really going to focus on the core non-premium part of the portfolio?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is -- the first thing is I hope you're right that the consumer and the economy get better in 2010. So that's the first thing. What we did focus on in '08 and '09 was really on our mainstream core brands where consumers were looking for continue
componenttext: The answer is -- the first thing is I hope you're right that the consumer and the economy get better in 2010. So that's the first thing. What we did focus on in '08 and '09 was really on our mainstream core brands where consumers were looking for continued value with great brands. So that was something that we were able to provide them and talk to them about specifically through advertising and good merchandising. We continue to support Hershey's Bliss. We supported it strongly in year two in 2009. We'll support it against strongly in year three in 2010. So in that trade up space, we feel very good about how Bliss is performing. And so when you talk about mainstream and trade up, we have fairly well defined those strategies. We obviously are -- while we are not launching anything in the premium space right now, we don't think it's appropriate, that doesn't mean that we're not working on that within our innovation pipeline. And when you think about the entire year 2010, one of the drivers for us in terms of improving our volume is our new products program in 2010 will be stronger than what we had in 2009. That's not to say it's going to be in the premium space, but it will be stronger overall. So we're readying for when the market returns and premium might become a part of that, but we don't have anything that I can specifically talk about right now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you give a dollar number for many millions of  dollar increase in commodity cost that might be in 2010?
componenttext: Did you give a dollar number for many millions of  dollar increase in commodity cost that might be in 2010?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Last year we gave one. Given the year-on-year increase, it's not nearly as large of an increase this year and just given where the commodities market have been, they've just been more similar to last year. Certainly, there are input cost increases in
componenttext: No. Last year we gave one. Given the year-on-year increase, it's not nearly as large of an increase this year and just given where the commodities market have been, they've just been more similar to last year. Certainly, there are input cost increases in 2010. We just didn't put a number on it like last year because of different order magnitude.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm still struggling to reconcile the sales number in the fourth quarter with sort of price, volume and discontinued items. So if I look at your reported sales growth of 2.2%, one point of that was currency, so underlying up 1.2% x currency. You s
componenttext: I guess I'm still struggling to reconcile the sales number in the fourth quarter with sort of price, volume and discontinued items. So if I look at your reported sales growth of 2.2%, one point of that was currency, so underlying up 1.2% x currency. You said pricing was up 7%,  8% in the quarter and then the discontinued items were about two points of a drag? I'm getting to kind of an underlying volume go down about 4%. Does that math work? Or is there bigger drag in terms of the discontinued items?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's base volume declines, which as we said were, low single digits. There is a seasonal shift, which counts for roughly a point or so of sales. And then there's the discontinued items, which is not only the trades of Starbucks and Cacao Reserve, but i
componenttext: There's base volume declines, which as we said were, low single digits. There is a seasonal shift, which counts for roughly a point or so of sales. And then there's the discontinued items, which is not only the trades of Starbucks and Cacao Reserve, but it's also -- we had an online gifting business that was in our numbers in 2008 that was not in the numbers in 2009.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you think about the price -- the increases in the fourth quarter, it looked like,  clearly, in the third quarter was up double digits and it slowed to 7%, 8% and the base volume responds when you think about the sequential improvement. Certainly, you s
componenttext: If you think about the price -- the increases in the fourth quarter, it looked like,  clearly, in the third quarter was up double digits and it slowed to 7%, 8% and the base volume responds when you think about the sequential improvement. Certainly, you saw that improvement, but relative to the pricing moderating, I'm not sure if you saw those kind of the sequential improvement as much as you would've liked to have seen. So is this still kind of in line with what you would have expected as pricing moderated that you would see a more moderate volume decline? And then my second question is just in terms of the C-store category. I think the category in the fourth quarter was up 2.3% which seems to be somewhat slower than the other channels. So I'm wondering if you can just talk about what's going on in that channel?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to pricing and conversion in the fourth quarter and throughout the year 2009, as I said, the marketplace behave somewhat pretty much as we would expect. We certainly had stronger conversion in the first half of the year than we would've model
componenttext: With respect to pricing and conversion in the fourth quarter and throughout the year 2009, as I said, the marketplace behave somewhat pretty much as we would expect. We certainly had stronger conversion in the first half of the year than we would've modeled, but we were pretty much on model in the back half of the year. So we're right about where we would have expected to be on the pricing and the conversion. With respect to convenience stores, obviously, the early part of 2009 had a much stronger pricing component in it. We were very pleased with our chocolate and non-chocolate takeaway in convenience channels throughout the fourth quarter. We underperformed on gum and that kind of dragged our takeaway down somewhat. Overall, we were up in a reasonable way in the fourth quarter. We feel very good about programming going forward in the convenience class of trade for 2010. So we would've expected, as the price increases kind of got normalized and we were lapping like increases at that convenience channels have slowed a bit in the fourth quarter and it did.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bert, just in terms of the growth margin expansion in 2010 that you're expecting, is at on top of the 2009 number that did include some of the LIFO gain in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Bert, just in terms of the growth margin expansion in 2010 that you're expecting, is at on top of the 2009 number that did include some of the LIFO gain in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is on top of the LIFO gain so we're not excluding that. I mentioned non-recurring because it doesn't happen frequently. And it was really primarily we use LIFO accounting and as we've reduced our inventories, as part of the supply chain transforma
componenttext: Yes, it is on top of the LIFO gain so we're not excluding that. I mentioned non-recurring because it doesn't happen frequently. And it was really primarily we use LIFO accounting and as we've reduced our inventories, as part of the supply chain transformation and working capital initiatives, we got that. So yes, it doesn't exclude that. It's incremental to that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you said it was about 100 basis point of a benefit in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And you said it was about 100 basis point of a benefit in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you quantify the cost related to the Cadbury transaction, with the advisory fee that you paid out in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And can you quantify the cost related to the Cadbury transaction, with the advisory fee that you paid out in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mentioned that they were about equal to the LIFO.
componenttext: I mentioned that they were about equal to the LIFO.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Lazar with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Lazar with Barclays Capital.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: From the perspective of your earnings guidance for 2010, I'm assuming that does not necessarily contemplate what you could do one way or another with the cash that has come up  throughout the call?
componenttext: From the perspective of your earnings guidance for 2010, I'm assuming that does not necessarily contemplate what you could do one way or another with the cash that has come up  throughout the call?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had mentioned last call, Dave, I think you were going to increase trade spends here and there just to kind of, I think it was ease consumers' transition to some of the new higher promoted price points? And given that it didn't necessarily come up spec
componenttext: You had mentioned last call, Dave, I think you were going to increase trade spends here and there just to kind of, I think it was ease consumers' transition to some of the new higher promoted price points? And given that it didn't necessarily come up specifically on the call, I assume there's nothing really out of the ordinary with that. You didn't need maybe more than you assume or less than you assume. How did that process go?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Andrew, when we talked about the price increases and trying to get to higher promoted price points, which is what we wanted to do within our business, I think that went about is what we would expected. Within the direct trade spending, obviously
componenttext: Actually, Andrew, when we talked about the price increases and trying to get to higher promoted price points, which is what we wanted to do within our business, I think that went about is what we would expected. Within the direct trade spending, obviously, our spend is much more around getting location and merchandising and less about price reduction. I guess the only abnormal thing I would say, or not abnormal, I guess it's going to become normal in 2009 was the return of couponing as a large part of the mix. Couponing was up pretty close to 30% across most of the categories in 2009. And so I think that's one of the elements of the mix that given where the consumer mindset is right now, would be about the only significant change I would point to in '09.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you've said you'll get into a lot more detail on sort of the productivity opportunity and what have you at CAGNY. I guess I'm trying to get a sense of the best we can do is you benchmark kind of where you're at in terms of your supply chain number
componenttext: I think you've said you'll get into a lot more detail on sort of the productivity opportunity and what have you at CAGNY. I guess I'm trying to get a sense of the best we can do is you benchmark kind of where you're at in terms of your supply chain numbers in '09 and assumption on your ongoing kind of productivity. It would seem like you still have some room if you benchmark you against peers. And obviously, a lot of your peers have been more recently ramping up their productivity efforts as well, given the environment. So I'm trying to get a sense of as you get into the CAGNY, can you say that these are programs that will be more ongoing in nature? Meaning, things for which the cost you'll absorb in the P&L as you go rather than necessarily incremental sort of charges like we saw as part of the supply chain program?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we'll talk about is, as I said, sourcing and procurement opportunities, logistics and supply chain opportunities. And then also, as we look in the longer term the way we use sales technology and work with retail partners, there's an opportuni
componenttext: I think what we'll talk about is, as I said, sourcing and procurement opportunities, logistics and supply chain opportunities. And then also, as we look in the longer term the way we use sales technology and work with retail partners, there's an opportunity for us to be much more efficient and that's one of the advantages of having a dedicated direct sales force. So we'll talk about those as all of those levers as ongoing productivity. We at minimum, obviously, want to offset inflation. And we feel pretty good that we've got programs that can do better than that into the future.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: Just three quick follow-ups, first would be are there any residual Cadbury expenses that you take in Q1? Or is that all in Q4?

componenttext: There's very little in Q1 and that's built into our 2010 forecast.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: If I could also ask about -- you mentioned early on about international growth over the last five years. Could you give us a feel for how that performed in 2009, exuding currency, of course?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In 2009, you're quite right. Currency was quite a big impact and it was a drag for the first three quarters. But if you exclude currency, we had growth in all of our markets, organic growth in all of our markets, including or excluding, if you want, the V
componenttext: In 2009, you're quite right. Currency was quite a big impact and it was a drag for the first three quarters. But if you exclude currency, we had growth in all of our markets, organic growth in all of our markets, including or excluding, if you want, the Van Houten business that we acquired last January.

componenttext: But could you give a composite of what international growth -- I guess what percentages are your total sales or give us some feel for that?

componenttext: No, we don't provide separate sales figures on the international business.

componenttextpreview: Can you say how much it was up for the year then?
componenttext: Can you say how much it was up for the year then?

componenttext: We'll cover it. We'll release it in the K and we'll talk a little bit about it at CAGNY in terms of where we were in 2009.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final question is regarding your market share and you had a number of unique factors in this quarter like Cacao Reserve and Starbucks that were kind of weighing on your volumes. So excluding that, it looks like your market share would've been down a li
componenttext: My final question is regarding your market share and you had a number of unique factors in this quarter like Cacao Reserve and Starbucks that were kind of weighing on your volumes. So excluding that, it looks like your market share would've been down a little bit or flat. Is that a good number, you believe, for the fourth quarter, I'm talking here?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I would say I wouldn't necessarily want to get into decomposing the building blocks by brand or by event. We expected that we would lose share in the fourth quarter. It was largely due to premium and drug. We lost 1.9 share points in the drug clas
componenttext: I guess I would say I wouldn't necessarily want to get into decomposing the building blocks by brand or by event. We expected that we would lose share in the fourth quarter. It was largely due to premium and drug. We lost 1.9 share points in the drug class and trade, which is a pretty meaningful class of trade for us in the fourth quarter. Those were the two biggest drivers. I don't think you can really decompose and say it's due to a brand or it's due to something. It really is those two events. Overall, we gained 1/10 of a share point FDMxC in 2009. We think that with everything, all of the moving parts in the marketplace that that's a reasonable performance and we would expect to be able to continue that in 2010.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the guidance or the cadence you've given in terms of helping modeling out profits and gross margins, it sounds like it's kind of front half loaded with pricing and cost savings flowing through more in the first half of the year than the second
componenttext: In terms of the guidance or the cadence you've given in terms of helping modeling out profits and gross margins, it sounds like it's kind of front half loaded with pricing and cost savings flowing through more in the first half of the year than the second half. Is your expectation for cost inflation that it will be higher in the second half than the first half? Or should we just think about it as being kind of consistent across the year?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The way we're looking at right now is we've built all of our expectations into our standard cost. And as a result, we use standard, obviously, as the way we reflect our gross margins. So it's evenly spread throughout the quarters. The one point that I wou
componenttext: The way we're looking at right now is we've built all of our expectations into our standard cost. And as a result, we use standard, obviously, as the way we reflect our gross margins. So it's evenly spread throughout the quarters. The one point that I would say is dairy, obviously. We've made certain assumptions around dairy and we think that, that will increase some, but not spike to the levels that we saw in 2008 when there was drought in Australia and New Zealand and things like that. And then the global supply chain transformation, you've already mentioned, which as we've ended the program, there are still some incremental benefits. And by the time you get to around mid-year, that equalizes.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if I were to understand, if there's any variability to the standard cost forecast in 2010, it's really going to be dairy that would drive it and not the other inputs?
componenttext: So if I were to understand, if there's any variability to the standard cost forecast in 2010, it's really going to be dairy that would drive it and not the other inputs?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that that there could be, obviously, pricing that occurs in commodity variability. But yes, dairy certainly is the one that has the most potential to impact. The other element, again, that we mentioned which aids the first half is that the pri
componenttext: I would say that that there could be, obviously, pricing that occurs in commodity variability. But yes, dairy certainly is the one that has the most potential to impact. The other element, again, that we mentioned which aids the first half is that the pricing which remains built into the P&L on Valentine's, and particularly Easter, because we ship a lot of Valentine in the fourth quarter, is certainly front end loaded.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have one quick question about mix. I understand the premium category is slowing down. Are there opportunities within your margins to actually move up the mix either between single serve? Or is it getting -- reducing the bags or is there a channel shift?
componenttext: I have one quick question about mix. I understand the premium category is slowing down. Are there opportunities within your margins to actually move up the mix either between single serve? Or is it getting -- reducing the bags or is there a channel shift? Anywhere that you think that there is a mix component outside of pure cost savings and supply chain in this environment and can you talk about that a little bit?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: There always are opportunities and we actually think very much of that with respect to our planning. When we plan out customer plans and we plan out against promoting pack size, et cetera, we look at mix continuously. I think that continuing to grow in co
componenttext: There always are opportunities and we actually think very much of that with respect to our planning. When we plan out customer plans and we plan out against promoting pack size, et cetera, we look at mix continuously. I think that continuing to grow in convenience, our King Size business continuing to grow, those are things that are very positive and favorable with respect to mix. And I think when you look at 2010 versus 2009, there isn't any real significant change in the portfolio we expect to sell that would tell you will have a significant mix shift in 2010. But it is something that we are always working towards to make sure that we take advantage of either more profitable customers and/or classes of trade.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Dreyer with Gabelli and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Dreyer with Gabelli and Company.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In looking at Cadbury, did that change from the management or Board perspective the level of leverage that you'd be comfortable with as  a company? And also there was some talk about being open to M&A, how does this change your fine tuning on thoughts on
componenttext: In looking at Cadbury, did that change from the management or Board perspective the level of leverage that you'd be comfortable with as  a company? And also there was some talk about being open to M&A, how does this change your fine tuning on thoughts on globalization strategy whether future M&A would come in existing markets, international markets or domestically?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we said in the past in terms of international markets and it's not unlike a lot of other organizations. We certainly have a greater focus on emerging markets. If you see where we've gone in the past, we've had a good Mexican business for quite som
componenttext: I think we said in the past in terms of international markets and it's not unlike a lot of other organizations. We certainly have a greater focus on emerging markets. If you see where we've gone in the past, we've had a good Mexican business for quite some time. We entered into a joint venture in Brazil, same in India. We're active in a manufacturing JV and in China. And there are other markets that are interesting to us. I think we said in the past that in terms of the European market, it's more mature, perhaps more difficult to get into. So emerging market because of the faster growth rates and the living standard just increasing there. So that continues to be our focus. In terms of do we have a different perspective on leverage, I think not. We've always said that we very much value the A rating that we have. As you would expect, we did an awful lot of modeling and discussions around different leverage levels. But philosophically, we intend to have a strong balance sheet and the whole capital structure discussion really is a Board level discussion which the Board has its own awful lot of input into. So I don't think it has changed the way we approach it.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Palmer with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Palmer with UBS.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Hershey results remind me a little bit over a decade ago when the beer industry and its players started to accept that low volume and perhaps stable per capita consumption was the reality for a long time. And pricing, by the large players, became the
componenttext: The Hershey results remind me a little bit over a decade ago when the beer industry and its players started to accept that low volume and perhaps stable per capita consumption was the reality for a long time. And pricing, by the large players, became the repeating driver of the top line, and CapEx was lower than appreciation for a long time, driving above average free cash flow. It somewhat looks like Hershey today. Is it possible that even after the consumer gets its feet under it that the U.S. chocolate players accept that long-term per capita increase in consumption are simply not going to be realistic long term? And that we could be seeing the beginning of a period which price increases with heavy reinvestment in advertising is a virtuous cycle and a healthy earnings driver for perhaps several years?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I think what I would tell you is that the category has consistently grown 3% to 4% for many, many years. The drivers are different depending on the set of circumstances. Some years, it's price increases. Some years, it's volume from innovation. Som
componenttext: David, I think what I would tell you is that the category has consistently grown 3% to 4% for many, many years. The drivers are different depending on the set of circumstances. Some years, it's price increases. Some years, it's volume from innovation. Some years, it's price increases. Some years, it's volume from innovation. Some years, it's base volume ; other volumes, it's been mix in terms of some of the shifting between either gum and mint and chocolate. But the category has been fairly consistent and robust. In a difficult economic time, it actually was even better than historical last year. This year it happened to be driven by relative increases in price. We're very pleased that the conversion has been better. Unit conversion has been stronger than what the pricing models would've told us. As we continue to look at our business going forward, we view this as a very dynamic on trend category. It's an advantaged category and we're going to make the appropriate investments in it to drive growth here. I don't view it as a category that's doesn't have the capability to continue to be advantaged and drive good growth for us into the future. Pricing actions in 2008/'09 were necessary given the commodity talk cost structure that we encountered and that happens from time to time in this business. But it's not a signal that the only growth in this category can come from pricing.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Jon Cox with Kepler.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I can come back to the commodity price question, you've not mentioned anything about pricing. But it seems to me that the cocoa prices, sugar prices, milk prices are all going upwards. I'm just wondering what you might have planned.  I know you sort of
componenttext: If I can come back to the commodity price question, you've not mentioned anything about pricing. But it seems to me that the cocoa prices, sugar prices, milk prices are all going upwards. I'm just wondering what you might have planned.  I know you sort of ducked the question a little bit in terms of pricing for this year. It seems that you're going to have increase prices and I think Cadbury alluded to that last week as they were sort of partly being taken over. But they were saying they would need to increase prices as well. I can't see any reason you can't increase prices. I wonder if you can just comment on that to start with, please.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not going to talk about any kind of a forward looking at pricing structure. It's just not something that we're going to do. That's competitive categories dynamic and we just are not going to comment on it in public.
componenttext: We're not going to talk about any kind of a forward looking at pricing structure. It's just not something that we're going to do. That's competitive categories dynamic and we just are not going to comment on it in public.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask you about your sort of potential M&A activity. You alluded to the fact potentially in some of the emerging markets. I was wondering if you can just maybe be a bit more specific with regards to maybe where you might be looking to expand
componenttext: If I could just ask you about your sort of potential M&A activity. You alluded to the fact potentially in some of the emerging markets. I was wondering if you can just maybe be a bit more specific with regards to maybe where you might be looking to expand because obviously at home, it looks like pretty much everything's done there. But I'm just wondering what about Europe, for example? Or is it mainly you'd be looking more for the emerging markets then?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Bert's commented on it earlier. We have looked at emerging markets and made acquisitions, over the last several years and/or have joint ventures, Brazil, manufacturing joint venture in China, a joint venture in India. Certainly, we've made an acqu
componenttext: I think Bert's commented on it earlier. We have looked at emerging markets and made acquisitions, over the last several years and/or have joint ventures, Brazil, manufacturing joint venture in China, a joint venture in India. Certainly, we've made an acquisition in Southeast Asia, one in Mexico in the last few years. So emerging markets continues to be where we're looking. And that's about all I would say. As Bert said, the attractive growth rate in some of those economies going forward are what we we're looking at.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, my name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to The Hershey Company Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mark Pogharian, you may begin your
componenttext: Good morning, my name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to The Hershey Company Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mark Pogharian, you may begin your conference.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Dave West, President and CEO; Bert Alfonso, Senior Vice President and CFO; and I will represent Hershey on this morning's call.
componenttext: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Dave West, President and CEO; Bert Alfonso, Senior Vice President and CFO; and I will represent Hershey on this morning's call. We also welcome those of you listening via the webcast. Let me remind everyone listening that today's conference call may contain statements which are forward looking. These statements are based on current expectations, which are subject to risk and uncertainty. Actual results may vary materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements because of factors, such as those listed in this morning's press release and in our 10-K for 2008 filed with the SEC.If you have not seen the press release, a copy is posted on our corporate website, www.hersheys.com, in the Investor Relations section. Included in the press release are consolidated balance sheet and a summary of consolidated statements of income prepared in accordance with GAAP, as well as a pro forma summary of consolidated statements of income quantitatively reconciled to GAAP.As we've said in the press release, the company uses these non-GAAP measures as key metric for evaluating performance internally. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to replace the presentation of financial results in accordance with GAAP; rather, the company believes the presentation of earnings, excluding certain items, provides additional information to investors to facilitate the comparison of past and present operations.We will discuss our fourth quarter 2009 results, excluding net pretax charges. The majority of these charges in both 2009 and 2008 are associated with the Global Supply Chain Transformation program. These pretax charges were $26.5 million and $79.7 million in the fourth quarters of 2009 and 2008. Our discussion of any future projections will also exclude the impact of net charges related to these business realignment initiatives. I'll now turn it over to Dave West.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Let me start with a few comments on recent events with respect to Cadbury plc. I assume that everyone on the call has had an opportunity to read our November 18 and January 22 press releases. After a thorough and complete examination, manage
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. Let me start with a few comments on recent events with respect to Cadbury plc. I assume that everyone on the call has had an opportunity to read our November 18 and January 22 press releases. After a thorough and complete examination, management and the Board of Directors unanimously concluded not to make an offer for Cadbury. Our Board of Directors and management team remain extremely confident in Hershey’s consumer-driven strategy and in the company's ability to execute and deliver long-term value for all stockholders. We will evaluate future acquisition opportunities in the same disciplined manner to ensure appropriate fit within our financial and strategic framework. We'll continue to follow this disciplined approach, and we'll continue to invest in Hershey’s existing brands and global infrastructure. With close to a 45% share of the U.S. chocolate market and strong and growing businesses in Canada and Mexico and nearly a 20% compounded annual growth rate outside of the U.S. and Canada over the past five years, we continue to be encouraged by our position in the marketplace and confident in continuing future success.Now for a discussion on our results. I'm very pleased with Hershey's fourth quarter and full year performance. We finished the year on solid footing and over delivered on our earnings per share objective by growing adjusted earnings per share 15% year-over-year. We achieved this in an extremely challenging environment that included global economic uncertainty and challenging consumer conditions, commodity spot market price volatility, the implementation and execution of a major price increase, the continued rollout and evolution of our consumer-driven approach to core brand investment, as well as the completion of our Global Supply Chain Transformation program. Despite these challenges, we delivered net sales and EPS growth that was significantly greater than the profile we shared with you at this time a year ago. For the full year 2009, net sales increased a bit more than 4% on a constant currency basis, up 3.2% reported. Gross and EBIT margin expanded meaningfully and our balance sheet and cash flow were very strong. We made excellent progress in 2009, and we look forward to delivering on our financial targets for a third consecutive year in 2010.In terms of Hershey's marketplace performance, for the 12 and 52 weeks ending January 2, 2010, using our custom database, and this is in channels that account for over 80% of our Retail business, total confections category retail consumer takeaway was up a strong 6% for the 12 weeks ending January 2, and it was up 7.2% for the year 2009. As a reminder, these channels include food, drug and mass. And mass here includes Wal-Mart and convenience stores.This growth rate is higher than the FDMx data that most of you received from IRI or Nielsen on a quad basis. FDMx only captures about half of our retail takeaway and excludes one of our largest mass customers, with whom we had performed well and excludes C-stores. In addition, it also excludes value and club format stores.Within food, drug and mass here excluding Wal-Mart and convenience, so FDMxC, the category also continues to grow. In 2009, the CMG category in FDMxC increased 4.4%, greater than the historical growth rate which is usually around 3% to 4%. In the fourth quarter, the CMG category was up 4%. Again, this is excluding Wal-Mart. As we look to 2010, we would expect historical growth rates to prevail in the category.Total Hershey FDMxC retail takeaway of 2.6 in the fourth quarter was less than the category, and as we expected resulted in a market share loss of 0.4 points. The decline was primarily driven by our decision to exit premium chocolates, Cacao Reserve, Starbucks and Joseph Schmidt, all of which played a role in gifting last year. And it contributed -- and it was also contributed to by the previously mentioned challenges in the drug class of trade. For the full year 2009 in FDMxC, the category grew 4.4%. Hershey retail takeaway for the year was 4.7%, resulting in a share gain for the year 2009 of 0.1 points. Our marketplace results in measured channels were driven by our success in the food and convenience classes of trade. Our continued growth in these two areas is a result of the targeted investments we make. Our in-store sales force remains a competitive advantage and has been a large part of our success. It differentiates us from our competitors. The investments we have made and will continue to make in Retail resources will be augmented by additional efforts in consumer insights, in-store merchandising and programming and will ensure we bring confectionery ideas and solutions to retailers to drive profitable growth for both Hershey and our customers.For the full-year 2009 in the food class of trade, the category grew 6%. With Hershey retail takeaway for the year up 6.3%, resulting in a share gain of 0.1 points. Fourth quarter food class of trade growth was 7.7% with Hershey takeaway at 7.3%, a bit lower than the category reflecting the earlier reference to Premium segment performance. As a result, food channel market share was off 0.1 points in the quarter. Hershey's Q4 class of trade in chocolate, the takeaway was up 7%. Again, a bit lower than the category with share off 0.1 points. Our non-chocolate foods takeaway was up 15.3%, resulting in a market share gain of 0.4 points in non-chocolate. These results were driven by core brand performance with Hershey's Bliss, Reese's, Kit Kat and Twizzlers retail takeaway, up double digits in the food class trade. We enjoyed solid Halloween sell-through, resulting in Hershey gaining one-full market share point for Halloween in food class of trade. And we did see slight improvement in our Kisses franchise and food, with takeaway up low-single digits due to advertising responsiveness to our baking merchandising and couponing.As it relates to the overall Halloween and holiday seasons, as expected in Q4, total seasonal category retail sales were slightly up versus year ago. Specifically in FDMx, Halloween retail category dollar growth was up 1.3%, and Hershey FDMx Halloween performance was in line with our expectations, as we gained 0.3 market share points, driven by the solid performance in the food class of trade. FDMx holiday retail category growth was up about 1.6%. Hershey's holiday performance, as expected, was soft, given the discretionary challenges related to gifting and our decision to discontinue certain premium products that were in the marketplace last year or that would be in 2008 in the fourth quarter.We talked a little bit about C-store, where the category was up 2.3% in the fourth quarter. In the fourth quarter, Hershey C-store takeaway increased 3.7%, resulting in a share gain of 0.3 points. In Q4, Hershey C-store chocolate and non-chocolate takeaway was up 5% and 7.2%, respectively. These gains were driven by core brand advertising, in-store selling and merchandising and solid programming, including an NCAA College Football promotion supported by on-air advertising, a nostalgic standard bar program leveraging Hershey's iconic brands and the king-size launch of TWIZZLERS PULL 'N PEEL.As we stated in October, the drug class of trade continue to be a drag on our overall Q4 FDMxC marketplace results, with Hershey drug channel market share declining 1.9 points in the fourth quarter. The changes in our go-to-market model have not driven the type of performance in the drug class of trade relative to its success in other formats. As we entered 2010, we have worked with key drug retail customers toward a mutually acceptable strategy that will drive category customer and Hershey growth. However, this channel will most likely remain a headwind on our overall marketplace performance during the first part of the year.As we look at 2010, we have many exciting products, promotions and programs in place, including an NCAA Final Four Basketball promotion following up on a very successful 2009 event. Sponsorship for the blockbuster Iron Man 2 movie starring Robert Downey, Jr. increased levels of Valentine's and Easter support, the continued rollout of Hershey's Special Dark, Almond Joy and York Pieces, as well as Hershey's Bliss white chocolate and the launch of selected limited editions, including Kit Kat Dark and Thingamajig, both back by popular demand from retailers. We have other innovation plan for the second half, which we'll share with you as the year unfolds.Additionally, full year advertising expense will increase approximately 25% to 30% year-over-year. We'll continue to support previously mentioned core brands, particularly Hershey's, Reese's, Hershey's Kisses and Bliss, Twizzlers and Kit Kat, as well as new core brand advertising campaigns for the Almond Joy, Mounds and York brands. We'll also continue to build on a consumer insights work we started in 2009. Understanding consumers and identifying trends is critical. And as category captain, we take our obligation to providing category solutions to the retail very seriously. We're committed to the proprietary insights work we have completed to date, and we'll continue to develop on an ongoing basis, as it is a critical part of our success. We'll share some of this work with you at CAGNY.Let me wrap up my comments. Despite the macroeconomic challenges facing the consumer, the category continues to grow across Retail channels, in both measured and non-measured outlets. Our advertising, consumer investments and insights work will enable Hershey to consistently and predictively achieve its financial targets. We expect 2010 net sales growth to be within our 3% to 5% long-term objective. Additionally, we have good visibility into our full year cost structure and expect our ongoing growth and adjusted earnings per share diluted to be within our long-term objective of 6% to 8%.As we look to the long term, Hershey has many opportunities to leverage its global brands and U.S. scale. Our consumer full model is working in the U.S., and this approach is being adopted in many of our international markets. Additionally, we are continuously examining our overall cost structure and believe opportunities exist to maintain and/or improve margins while continually monitoring commodity market volatility. And we'll have again more on the cost structure at CAGNY.Our balance sheet and cash flows remain strong, and we will continue to be disciplined, but open to sources of growth via M&A. Our executive management team and the Board of Directors are confident that this approach will continue to build value for all Hershey shareholders. I'll now turn it over to Bert Alfonso, who will provide you with some additional financial details.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Net sales and adjusted earnings per share diluted from operations for the full year 2009 exceeded the initial ranges we communicated at the beginning of last year. Solid efforts during the year by the sales, marke
componenttext: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Net sales and adjusted earnings per share diluted from operations for the full year 2009 exceeded the initial ranges we communicated at the beginning of last year. Solid efforts during the year by the sales, marketing, supply chain and finance groups result in strong price realization, while volume declines were less than anticipated. Overall, we're pleased with our financial and marketplace performance in 2009, given the volatile environment in both commodity and financial markets, as well as the pressures facing consumers. Fourth quarter consolidated net sales of 1,407,000,000  increased 2.2% versus the prior year. Adjusted EPS diluted of $0.63 increased 7%, primarily due to price realization, supply chain savings and a lower effective income tax rate, which more than offset the impact of volume decline, higher input cost and increased marketing investment. In addition, fourth quarter results include a non-occurring benefit from LIFO accounting related to targeted inventory reductions. These essentially offset the cost of advisory fees related to our consideration of a transaction with Cadbury. For the full year, net sales increased 3.2% or 4.2% on a constant-currency basis, resulting in adjusted earnings per share diluted of $2.17, up 15.4%. In the fourth quarter, sales gains were driven primarily by pricing and improvements in our International business. Mid-single digit pricing gains were partially offset by expected base volume declines associated with the U.S. pricing actions, and previously communicated decisions to close our On-line Gift business and discontinue certain premium chocolate products. Importantly in the fourth quarter, base volume declines improved sequentially from mid- to low-single digits. As we communicated in October, due to timing, shipments of Valentine and Easter season cards were lower in the fourth quarter of 2009 versus 2008. All [ph](24:44) season benefit from the shipped into the first quarter of 2010. Also, foreign currency exchange was about a one-point benefit in the quarter, a change from quarters 1 to 3, in which FX detracted from sales growth.
