Dave provided details related to our marketplace performance, so I'll now focus on the review of the P&L, balance sheet and cash flow starting with gross margin.  During the fourth quarter, adjusted gross margin increased 330 basis points, primarily driven by net price realization, supply chain savings, productivity and lower levels of inventory that led to a favorable non-recurring 100 basis point benefit from LIFO accounting. These margin gains more than offset higher input costs of about 150 basis points, primarily reflecting total consolidated cost increases for raw materials. Higher employee benefit costs, primarily pension expense at our manufacturing facilities, also reduced adjusted gross margin in the fourth quarter. For the full year 2009, adjusted gross margin was 38.9% versus 35.8% in 2008, up 310 basis points as pricing and productivity initiatives, inclusive of the Global Supply Chain Transformation program offset 200 basis points of unfavorable input costs. Adjusted EBIT margin increased 10 basis points in the fourth quarter, as higher gross margin was substantially offset by advertising, up 50% in the quarter, marking the expenses including consumer promotions; employee-related costs, including incentive and pension expense; and advisory fees related to our consideration of a transaction with Cadbury. Adjusted EBIT for the full year increased 11.7% with EBIT margin up 120 basis points from 15% to 16.2%. The increase was driven by higher gross margin, partially offset by increased advertising investment and employee-related costs. For the year, advertising increased 50% to $241 million.Now let me provide a brief update on our International businesses. During 2009, we made good progress in the international markets where we operate. Our International group faced many of the same challenges as the U.S. counterparts, including implementation of price increases in certain markets, economically impacted consumers and volatile foreign exchange rates. Overall, on a constant-currency basis and excluding the Van Houten business that we acquired earlier in the year, International fourth quarter sales were up mid-single digits. So our reported International profitability was down versus year ago, driven by brand building and investments in key markets. As we look to 2010, we'll continue to invest in our strategic international markets to increase the distribution of our products, enhance brand awareness and further develop our go-to-market capabilities.Moving down the P&L. For the fourth quarter, interest expense decreased, coming in at $22 million versus $25 million last year. For the year, interest expense was $90 million versus $98 million in 2008. The fourth quarter and full year both benefited from lower short-term rates in our commercial paper and improvements in working capital. Lower debt levels also contributed to the lower interest expense, as we significantly reduced our short-term debt during the year. In 2010, we expect interest expense to be in the $90 million to $100 million range.The tax rate in the fourth quarter was 33.6%, down 210 basis points versus year ago. For the full year, the tax rate was 35.5%, down 50 basis points versus year ago. The change in the tax rate result in a $0.02 EPS benefit in the quarter and the full year. The improvement was primarily due to foreign tax benefits and a lower-than-expected tax rate in our Monterrey, Mexico business. For the full year 2010, we expect the effective income tax rate to be about 35%, primarily due to an increase in the federal manufacturing deduction from 6% to 9%. Additionally, on a quarterly basis, we expect the tax rate to be smoother in 2010 versus 2009, about 36% during the first half of the year and 34% in the back half.In the fourth quarter of 2009, weighted average shares outstanding on a diluted basis were 229.6 million versus 228.5 million shares in 2008, leading to adjusted EPS diluted of $0.63, up 6.8% versus year ago. For the year, shares outstanding were approximately 225 million, consistent with 2008 levels. And adjusted EPS diluted for the full year was $2.17, up approximately 15%.Turning now to our balance sheet and cash flow. At the end of the year, net trading capital decreased versus last year, resulting in cash flow benefit of $156 million. Accounts receivable were down $45 million and remain extremely current and of high quality. Year-over-year accounts receivable days outstanding improved about 4 days. Inventory declined $73 million and accounts payable increased $38 million. This represents the third consecutive year reductions in net trading capital, which is a key focus area. We expect net trading capital to further improve in 2010, but not at the rates achieved in 2009. In terms of other specific cash flow items, capital additions, including software, were $39 million for the quarter and $145 million for the full year, in line with the upper end of our previously revised capital expenditure range. For 2010, we are targeting total capital additions to be in the range of $150 million to $160 million. Depreciation and amortization was $44 million in the quarter and includes accelerated depreciation related to the Global Supply Chain Transformation of $1 million. For the full year 2009, depreciation and amortization expense was $182 million, of which accelerated depreciation and amortization was about $4 million. In 2010, we are forecasting total depreciation and amortization of about $180 million to $185 million.Dividends paid during the quarter were $66 million, bringing the full year total to $263 million. We did not acquire any stock in the fourth quarter related to the current repurchase program. And there is $100 million outstanding on the current authorization that the Board approved in December 2006. Cash on hand at year end was $254 million, up $217 million versus year ago. Our cash management strategy this year has been to pay down short-term debt with excess cash. Short-term debt and the current portion of long-term debt at year end was $39 million, down $462 million versus a year ago. And as it relates to our short-term cash needs, the company is currently well positioned. Our cash flow has been strong, and we expect that to continue in 2010. And 97% of our current debt or $1.5 billion is in fixed-rate notes with maturity starting in 2011.During the year, we made voluntary contributions to our qualified pensions plans of $9 million in the quarter and $54 million for the year to improve our funded status. In 2009, our pension asset returns were in line with that of the market indices. The increase in pension assets will result in reduced pension expense of approximately $14 million or $0.04 a share in 2010. Let me now provide an update on the Global Supply Chain Transformation program.  During the fourth quarter of 2009, the program was concluded. I am pleased to confirm that the construction of our Monterrey, Mexico facility is complete. Total charges for the program were $629 million and included $85 million of non-cash pension settlement charges. Excluding pension settlement charges, total project costs were $544 million, below the estimate of $575 million to $600 million previously communicated. And except for possible non-cash pension settlement charges, the company does not expect any significant charges related to the Global Supply Chain Transformation program in 2010. In 2009, total GAAP charges related to the program were $99 million. A total of these charges reduced reported 2009 earnings by $0.27. During the fourth quarter, we reported Global Transformation charges of $26 million pretax, of which $24 million was related to non-cash pension settlement charges.  The cumulative savings for the program are $160 million and in line with our forecast. The estimate of total ongoing annual savings by the end of 2010 is $175 million to $185 million, with incremental savings being realized earlier in the year.This morning, we also announced a 7.6% increase in our quarterly dividend on our common shares. This increase is a result of the company's strong balance sheet and our confidence in the current business model. We believe our current strategies will enable the company to continue to meaningfully generate predictable cash flow from operations. As such, we continue to have Board-level discussions related to capital structure and deployment of excess cash. And we'll continue to explore M&A-related growth opportunities.Let me close by providing some context on our 2010 outlook. We have made investments, where we have made investments, the business has responded. As such, we will continue to do the right things for our core brands and at key retail customers and channels that are driving our growth. During the first half of the year, we'll continue with the distribution and rollout of our new products, as well as new core brand investments behind Almond Joy, Mounds and York brands. As a result, we expect full year 2010 net sales growth to be within our 3% to 5% stated long-term objective.At this point, we have a good assessment of our 2010 cost input basket. As a result, we expect gross margin expansion in 2010 although not at the same level achieved in 2009. The full year increase in gross margin will be driven by different factors, including seasonal pricing and Global Supply Chain Transformation savings, that will be achieved during the first half of the year. We estimate that advertising will increase 25% to 30%, supporting core brands in both the U.S. and international markets. During the year, we'll also continue to invest in consumer insight analysis, that will benefit all classes of trade, including the drug channel, to address current challenges.At Hershey, we are committed to category leadership, and we'll strive to be the confectionery solution for all customers and in all channels. As a result, we expect to achieve growth of adjusted earnings per share in 2010, given our long-term objective of 6% to 8%.To conclude and as you work on your models, I remind you that the full year 2010 gains in net sales and margins will most likely be driven in the first half and resulting from the following factors: The timing of seasonal pricing, particularly the Easter; newly-launched products achieving targeted ACV levels by midyear; incremental Global Supply Chain Transformation savings are programmed for earlier in the year; foreign exchange, which was a headwind for the first 2/3 of 2009 will most likely benefit the first couple of quarters; and a lower tax rate throughout the entire year. We will now open it up to questions.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess my questions revolve around the advertising efficacies. You seem quite confident about the top line for 2010, in kind of how you progressed in 2009. Maybe it's a discussion for CAGNY, but I guess with the 50% boost in advertising and not really mu
componenttext: I guess my questions revolve around the advertising efficacies. You seem quite confident about the top line for 2010, in kind of how you progressed in 2009. Maybe it's a discussion for CAGNY, but I guess with the 50% boost in advertising and not really much change in share, just kind of how are you judging the success of that program? And also, Dave, I think you said that one of the company's competitive advantages is the in-store effort. And maybe that's a bridge between the advertising-to-sales ratio that you show versus kind of what Wrigley was spending and what some of the other companies spend which is above your rate. And maybe that's the difference in terms of how we're viewing how much advertising you really need to put back into the business over time. You follow it?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I can. I think, Eric, there's a couple of, series of questions in there, and they're all right on target in terms of how we're thinking about that business. And we will provide I think more depth for you at CAGNY. Let me try and take them on for y
componenttext: I think I can. I think, Eric, there's a couple of, series of questions in there, and they're all right on target in terms of how we're thinking about that business. And we will provide I think more depth for you at CAGNY. Let me try and take them on for you right now. With respect to advertising to sales, we certainly don't think about it as, the total company should have a ratio of x percent. We are certainly looking at it brand by brand. Each of the brands is positioned in a way that it is speaking to an either a need state or a certain set of consumers. And we believe that the way we are positioning the brands, that those brands are incremental, at least somewhat incremental. So when we start to talk about bringing Mounds, Almond Joy and York, supporting it with advertising for the first time in many, many years, we do that because we think they're positioned in a unique way with consumers, where we think that we'll get an incremental lift from that so that we're not switching brands with each other. We look at each of the brands on a monthly basis in terms of the ROI in the list. what we're very encouraged, for example, we started Twizzlers and Kit Kat advertising in 2009. We drove mid- to high-single digit takeaway when you look at them across all channels on Twizzlers and Kit Kat, for example, in 2009. And the advertising responsiveness was very good. Reese's, which we've been on-air for a number of years, continues -- the two-cup Reese's business continues to be up very, very strongly. So when you look at the response that we're getting, and we track it on a regular basis, we feel pretty good about it. And therefore, we think that it still makes sense as an investment. The important thing that I think we do with that advertising is we then couple the advertising and activate it at retail with our sales force. So our programming has been very dramatic. I think we talked about how we've been doing it with Easter and Halloween. We've been running seasonal-specific advertising. And then we activate that at retail with the sales force. So we think we've got it lined up, and it seems to be working very well, in the face of a significant price increase of roughly 10% to 11% across the line, which we took in August of '08 and went into the marketplace, and even higher than 10% on some of the promoted price points. We think that advertising is one of the reasons that we were able to improve the takeaway throughout the year. Our conversion and our volume declines certainly improved throughout the year. So as we head to 2010, we think the formula is right. We continue to add to advertising. We'll continue to invest in Retail. We have a little bit of carryover pricing obviously in the Valentine's and Easter seasons in the beginning of the year here. We'll have more brands on air. And so I think we think we have the right model here to derive some decent top line growth here in 2010.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the cost of that, the sales force versus the competition and that may be bridging the difference between the total company percentage of sales. Is that another way to look at it?
componenttext: And the cost of that, the sales force versus the competition and that may be bridging the difference between the total company percentage of sales. Is that another way to look at it?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think so, Eric. I also think that the comparison to the Wrigley advertising-to-sales numbers is a little misleading because, I think, you have to look at the total basket of spending, including trade promotion, couponing, et cetera. When you look at gum
componenttext: I think so, Eric. I also think that the comparison to the Wrigley advertising-to-sales numbers is a little misleading because, I think, you have to look at the total basket of spending, including trade promotion, couponing, et cetera. When you look at gum and mint, gum and mint tends to be a different -- it's a much more of a single, totally impulse-oriented category. It's something that doesn't have an aisle business per se. It doesn't have a seasonal component. So I think the drivers have been different historically in terms of the merchandising strategy. So I think the promotional lever in chocolate has tended to be more important. So when you look at the mix of what Wrigley would have spent historically in a gum and mint portfolio versus something that's for us more skewed towards chocolate and sugar, I don't think that those are apples-to-apples in terms of the comparison. But I do think that we're at a place with the brands. We think that as we come through 2010 here, we add Mounds, Almond Joy and York. We think we're at getting to competitive levels on those brands and feeling pretty good about the returns.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens with JPMorgan.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess judging from your remarks. Clearly, we've let the price increases on the single bars, and we do have this residual kind of seasonal price increase. So it sounds like, Dave, you're not really contemplating at this point another list price increase
componenttext: I guess judging from your remarks. Clearly, we've let the price increases on the single bars, and we do have this residual kind of seasonal price increase. So it sounds like, Dave, you're not really contemplating at this point another list price increase as we move through this year?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, I'm not going to talk about pricing in terms of anything going forward. What I will only talk about is what we've done in the past.
componenttext: Terry, I'm not going to talk about pricing in terms of anything going forward. What I will only talk about is what we've done in the past.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given then that perspective, at what point do your model show your volumes beginning to turn positive?
componenttext: Given then that perspective, at what point do your model show your volumes beginning to turn positive?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think, Terry, as you look at what we talked about for 2010, we'll have some carryover pricing, which is all we've announced at this point in time. And we need to add volumes, turn positive. Now obviously the business is a bit unique in the first pa
componenttext: Well I think, Terry, as you look at what we talked about for 2010, we'll have some carryover pricing, which is all we've announced at this point in time. And we need to add volumes, turn positive. Now obviously the business is a bit unique in the first part of the year here because we're still taking Valentine's and Easter to new promoted price points. They were price-protected last year. But we should start to see some volume gains as we get out through the year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess obviously, I was trying to get you to give us some sort of guidance on what kind of price volume algorithm you're contemplating on the top line. Maybe that should wait for CAGNY as well, unless you'd care to share it now.
componenttext: I guess obviously, I was trying to get you to give us some sort of guidance on what kind of price volume algorithm you're contemplating on the top line. Maybe that should wait for CAGNY as well, unless you'd care to share it now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'll pass.
componenttext: I think I'll pass.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jonathan Feeney with Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jonathan Feeney with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, just following-up on Eric's question. I recognize your answer that Wrigley isn't exactly comparable in terms of relative advertising. But could you give us -- I mean, clearly, you believe the relative advertising percentage you have right now isn't
componenttext: Dave, just following-up on Eric's question. I recognize your answer that Wrigley isn't exactly comparable in terms of relative advertising. But could you give us -- I mean, clearly, you believe the relative advertising percentage you have right now isn't adequate because you've done such a good job raising it. Is there a number or a range in terms of relative sales that you get to in 2011 or 2012 where you say no more 30%, 35%-type increases?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've been doing is, as I said, you have to recognize what we've been doing as we've been going along is not only getting to what we think our threshold and/or sustaining levels on the brand. We've added more brands throughout. So we started
componenttext: I think what we've been doing is, as I said, you have to recognize what we've been doing as we've been going along is not only getting to what we think our threshold and/or sustaining levels on the brand. We've added more brands throughout. So we started back in '08. We really focused first on Hershey's and Reese's and then the latter part of '08 and certainly in '09 on Kisses and getting to Kit Kat and Twizzlers through '09 and now in '10, adding in York, Mounds and Almond Joy. So we've been adding to the breadth, as well as getting those brands to what we think are sustaining levels of GRP. So I think we're now at the place where we have seven or eight core brands that we're promoting when you think about Hershey's Bliss and some of the work we're also doing on Ice Breakers. So we measure them all individually. And we will continue to view that as a good investment as long as the ROI is positive. And we look at the ROI on that spending, as well as the mix of the entire basket of promotion plus advertising. And we're making marginal spend decisions based on what is returning the best for our dollar. And as we continue to invest in brands like Reese's in the third year a fairly heavy copy, we're still seeing very good returns on that. So we're watching it. We'll continue to invest in it as long as it makes sense within the P&L framework, and it's driving good top line return.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: For Bert, when you think about your balance sheet right now, I mean, you're at least a turn and a half of EBITDA below the industry averages for investment-grade, perfectly stable, perfectly comfortable company that frankly aren't increasing their relativ
componenttext: For Bert, when you think about your balance sheet right now, I mean, you're at least a turn and a half of EBITDA below the industry averages for investment-grade, perfectly stable, perfectly comfortable company that frankly aren't increasing their relative advertising spend at 50%, 35% clips. You have $100 million share repurchase. I mean, you could be buying back 20% of this company if you wanted to and stay in the middle of those ranges. Why aren't you more aggressive in share repurchase right now? And do you plan to get more aggressive in the coming quarters?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the balance sheet, we ended the year quite pleased with our performance. As I mentioned, we have cash flow certainly at the upper ranges that we weren't able to generate in the past. We certainly value that, a credit. And as we talked wit
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the balance sheet, we ended the year quite pleased with our performance. As I mentioned, we have cash flow certainly at the upper ranges that we weren't able to generate in the past. We certainly value that, a credit. And as we talked with the Board, we announced this morning a dividend increase. With respect to other forms of getting value back to the shareholder, certainly that's a Board-level decision and a discussion which where we are today is the appropriate discussion to be having. So I would say that your observation is one that is a similar discussion as we're having internally.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that somewhat of a reflection of your, or Dave mentioned in his comments too, of your preference to keep some acquisition flexibility?
componenttext: Is that somewhat of a reflection of your, or Dave mentioned in his comments too, of your preference to keep some acquisition flexibility?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look at our capital structure in general, I think acquisition flexibility has always played a role. We were certainly a bit more conservative towards the back half of '08 and the majority of '09, as the market uncertainty really -- that made s
componenttext: Well, as we look at our capital structure in general, I think acquisition flexibility has always played a role. We were certainly a bit more conservative towards the back half of '08 and the majority of '09, as the market uncertainty really -- that made sense to us to preserve cash and to be more conservative with respect to what's going on in the market. As we see that starting to thaw a bit, we're encouraged by our cash flow, encouraged by the balance sheet that we do have. So I would say that M&A flexibility has always been part of our capital structure thinking, and that's no different going forward.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to get a sort of what your guiding to from an operating line perspective, and I just want to make sure I heard you right. If EPS is going to grow 6% to 8%, it sounds like pension and tax is going to provide 2% to 4% of that, and you got sa
componenttext: I'm just trying to get a sort of what your guiding to from an operating line perspective, and I just want to make sure I heard you right. If EPS is going to grow 6% to 8%, it sounds like pension and tax is going to provide 2% to 4% of that, and you got sales up 3% to 5%. So It sounds like operating profit growth is going to be flat to up 2%. Do I have that right?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're expecting a continuation of gross margin expansion this year. We have a number of things that are still quite positive for us. I mentioned the Supply Chain Transformation [Global Supply Chain Transformation]. We have incremental savings in t
componenttext: I mean, we're expecting a continuation of gross margin expansion this year. We have a number of things that are still quite positive for us. I mentioned the Supply Chain Transformation [Global Supply Chain Transformation]. We have incremental savings in that regard. We have a very active productivity program aside from that particular program. And I think we've mentioned in the past, now that we have our manufacturing footprint at a more stable basis, we see productivity opportunities in sort of inputs going in and inputs going out through that site. We're certainly expecting gross margin expansion below that. We already talked about 25% to 30% advertising increase. So my view on that is your observation on taxes is correct, and we do have a little bit of pension benefit. Interest we think will be a little bit higher as than it was this year, as rates start to climb, and we think that will happen more towards the back half of the year. So that's the only other component that we didn't talk about when we did give the range of $90 million to $100 million.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're going to have gross margin expansion, and I recognize all the things that you just listed in there. But when we look at where cocoa, dairy and sugar are, those look like pretty profound increases. And it sounds like you might have some nice hedges
componenttext: You're going to have gross margin expansion, and I recognize all the things that you just listed in there. But when we look at where cocoa, dairy and sugar are, those look like pretty profound increases. And it sounds like you might have some nice hedges on in terms of cocoa and sugar. And I doubt you're going to want to elaborate in when those are going to come off, but can you remind us how you buy dairy, and if we're looking at dairy prices, when we should think about those flowing through your P&L?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, our input cost in the current spot market are high. We have an active hedging program. And so what we're talking about in terms of gross margin expansion takes that into account, as well as the productivity which we mentioned, which is an off
componenttext: Yes, I mean, our input cost in the current spot market are high. We have an active hedging program. And so what we're talking about in terms of gross margin expansion takes that into account, as well as the productivity which we mentioned, which is an offset to the input costs. There is no forward market per se for fluid dairy, which is an important component for us. Dairy prices have started to increase. They're certainly off the lows. We're not expecting them to reach the 2008 highs during this year, but we do think there continues to be volatility in commodities, and we're watching it closely.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But is it a six-month lag? Is it a three-month lag from the spot dairy price? Is there any guidance you can give us on that?
componenttext: But is it a six-month lag? Is it a three-month lag from the spot dairy price? Is there any guidance you can give us on that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really give guidance on that.
componenttext: No, we don't really give guidance on that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: People have already asked about the cadence of the volume for 2010. I guess I'm curious about the market share. You were down 40 basis points in the fourth quarter, and you kind of described it, relate it to the premium gift items. Can you tell us how muc
componenttext: People have already asked about the cadence of the volume for 2010. I guess I'm curious about the market share. You were down 40 basis points in the fourth quarter, and you kind of described it, relate it to the premium gift items. Can you tell us how much of the market share decline was specifically related to that? And then, do you expect your share to improve quite a bit in the first half? Or should we expect market share to be kind of lagging in the first half and improving in the second?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what I would tell you on the market share is some of it is the premium obviously that we talked about, this Cacao Reserve and Starbucks and some of the gifting . Remember also that we had some continued difficulties in the drug class of trade
componenttext: Yes, I think what I would tell you on the market share is some of it is the premium obviously that we talked about, this Cacao Reserve and Starbucks and some of the gifting . Remember also that we had some continued difficulties in the drug class of trade. Some of that is premium and some of that was programming that we didn't lap very well. So I think those were the two big drivers. We had talked about those when we talked on the October call. So we were not surprised by the share loss in the fourth quarter. We had expected that we would lose share. As we go into 2010, we would expect that there'll be a little bit of continued pressure. Valentine's is again a holiday that's got a lot of premium and gifting in it. We may not perform quite as well there. We think we'll do better at Easter. We had a very good Easter last year, and we're very pleased with our Easter programming this year. And then as the year goes on, obviously, the advertising and other factors kick in. So I think, Rob, that the first quarter may look a little bit more in measured channels like the fourth did. But I think for the full year 2010, we would expect market share to be something that looks similar. Full year last year, we were up a tenth of a point, so I would kind of think about 2010 similarly to 2009 for the full year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the competitive structure of pricing and promotions that you see out there, are you seeing a rational environment? Are you seeing overly aggressive environment from your competitors? Or pretty much the same as you've always seen?
componenttext: When you look at the competitive structure of pricing and promotions that you see out there, are you seeing a rational environment? Are you seeing overly aggressive environment from your competitors? Or pretty much the same as you've always seen?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I don't think there's any way you can say it's pretty much like we've always seen because there is a significant change in pricing in the actual market last year. So we pretty much did what we said we were going to do. And I think that from a consume
componenttext: Well I don't think there's any way you can say it's pretty much like we've always seen because there is a significant change in pricing in the actual market last year. So we pretty much did what we said we were going to do. And I think that from a consumer and customer standpoint, we saw the reactions that we expected, pretty much as expected.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But your competition raised price also?
componenttext: But your competition raised price also?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, price. If you look at your syndicated data, pricing in the entire category is higher.
componenttext: I think, yes, price. If you look at your syndicated data, pricing in the entire category is higher.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Investments.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Investments.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: One question about the quarter itself, could you tell us what the volume decline was in the quarter? I think you said it improved sequentially, but can you put a dimension around that?
componenttext: One question about the quarter itself, could you tell us what the volume decline was in the quarter? I think you said it improved sequentially, but can you put a dimension around that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I had mentioned that -- and I think we both mentioned that there was a sequential improvement -- and from mid-single digits to low single digits [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes, David, I had mentioned that -- and I think we both mentioned that there was a sequential improvement -- and from mid-single digits to low single digits [indiscernible].

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s base volume.
componenttext: That’s base volume.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Base volume.
componenttext: Base volume.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Base volume was down low single digits. And then if we put in -- what are the effects of the withdrawal of the Starbucks and Cacao Reserve products in the gifting products? Can you give us a volume impact?
componenttext: Base volume was down low single digits. And then if we put in -- what are the effects of the withdrawal of the Starbucks and Cacao Reserve products in the gifting products? Can you give us a volume impact?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about it in the quarter, pricing was roughly 10%; that reflects the list pricing through the seasons. We had a low-single-digit base volume decline. We had a seasonal shift also in the quarter of roughly a point or so, if you wil
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think about it in the quarter, pricing was roughly 10%; that reflects the list pricing through the seasons. We had a low-single-digit base volume decline. We had a seasonal shift also in the quarter of roughly a point or so, if you will, and discontinued items. So if you think about those, those are worth another couple of points. We had Valentine's and Easter that will ship in 2010 that shipped in the fourth quarter of the year ago. So when you think about it, it's roughly 10% or so pricing, some low-single-digit base volume declines and then also then the discontinued and seasonal shifts that kind of take you down where you were. So I think you're talking about roughly, I guess, David roughly say 7% or 8% on the pricing and then you take then take the volume buy-in, it's low single -- the volume base low single digits off and then the seasonal and the discontinued items is another couple of points. And that will get you to where we were.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: FX in the quarter.
componenttext: FX in the quarter.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the question on the use of cash. The only thing that wasn't mentioned by, I think it was Jonathan who asked the question, was it seems pretty obvious you're not buying stock in the quarter when you're contemplating the largest acquisition in
componenttext: Going back to the question on the use of cash. The only thing that wasn't mentioned by, I think it was Jonathan who asked the question, was it seems pretty obvious you're not buying stock in the quarter when you're contemplating the largest acquisition in your history. So I'm not surprised by the fact that we didn't see any share repurchase. You did acknowledge, I think, also I think you said $100 million of an existing authorization so that's at your discretion to execute whenever you see fit, and I would assume that would be forthcoming. But I suppose, Dave, what I really want to get after is just the balance sheet leverage is it's just fabulously low relative to the rest of the sector. Is there anything here that is just obvious that would want to detract from buying back the stock in your opinion?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get into the specifics of what we're going to do with respect to the balance sheet. I think Bert covered it very well. We increased our dividend today or yesterday, announced it today. I think that that, again, we had record cash flows fr
componenttext: I'm not going to get into the specifics of what we're going to do with respect to the balance sheet. I think Bert covered it very well. We increased our dividend today or yesterday, announced it today. I think that that, again, we had record cash flows from operations in 2009 and feel very good about that position. We do have the remaining share repurchases and as Bert said, and I said it as well, we're open to M&A. It's always been something that's factored into our equation. And we want to leave those levers available. It's certainly a Board level conversation and we have them continually. So I do want to get into anything more specific than that, other than that we're really happy with the cash flow performance of the business in '09, and very pleased that our balance sheet and our finance folks here have done a great job.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a date already set for the next Board meeting?
componenttext: Is there a date already set for the next Board meeting?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you tell us what the date is?
componenttext: Can you tell us what the date is?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd rather not. I don't want to get into talking about our internal governance. Actually our base is not only reset for 2010, they're set for 2011. So it's really kind of not relevant.
componenttext: I'd rather not. I don't want to get into talking about our internal governance. Actually our base is not only reset for 2010, they're set for 2011. So it's really kind of not relevant.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just big picture, I feel like after this whole discussion about whether or not you're going to get involved in the Cadbury discussions or not, people now question whether or not the company really has any kind of sustainable top line growth. The U.S. cate
componenttext: Just big picture, I feel like after this whole discussion about whether or not you're going to get involved in the Cadbury discussions or not, people now question whether or not the company really has any kind of sustainable top line growth. The U.S. category has done well for many years and I think people just need to hear you talk about why this is a good category in your expectations. You already made a couple comments about 2010 in the volume numbers to Terry. But again, Dave, why are you confident that the top line can grow? And I believe your guidance at 3% to 5%. It's very strong relative to what we hear from other companies with U.S. operations. Can you give people some color on this and explain your confidence?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think at CAGNY, we'll certainly talk about the category. And we continue to believe we are at an advantaged category. It's expandable. It's highly impulse oriented. It's a destination category because of the seasonal component of it. Certainly, three or
componenttext: I think at CAGNY, we'll certainly talk about the category. And we continue to believe we are at an advantaged category. It's expandable. It's highly impulse oriented. It's a destination category because of the seasonal component of it. Certainly, three or four times a year, the retailer really has a desire to display the category. The category growth rate last year was, and this is in FDMxC, was up 4.4%. We're certainly looking at a long-term 3% to 4% growth rate category. And so when you think about our ability to be advantaged in that category and continue to grow with or ahead of that category growth rate, we feel very confident in our ability to do that. Our International business outside of the U.S. and Canada has been growing in almost 20% compound over the last five years. So that's a nice additive. We're pleased with that growth in terms of where we are, but then you also look at the rest of the world. And even despite Mars and Wrigley and Kraft and Cadbury, if Kraft and Cadbury closes, it's still a fragmented global category with opportunities out there to expand. And as Bert has already mentioned, we have a very strong balance sheet. So we feel good about where we're positioned. We feel that we did the right things in terms of taking a disciplined look at an asset that was available. It didn't work for us within the framework that we had established, but that doesn't mean that we're not highly confident in our business model.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to take a step back and look at your capacity utilization and whether there is a need to further shrink capacity. You commented that for this year, your volume declines were somewhat less than you had forecast. But I'm wondering whether you t
componenttext: I was hoping to take a step back and look at your capacity utilization and whether there is a need to further shrink capacity. You commented that for this year, your volume declines were somewhat less than you had forecast. But I'm wondering whether you take a broader step back to it goes February 2007 when you unveiled the Supply Chain Transformation program. Your capacity utilization then you were citing was in the low-60s and you want to get to about 85% by 2010. Are you still on track to do that? It would seem like the denominator or the production in place, you've made good progress in reducing. But just wondering, given the volume shift that we've seen, whether you're still on track to get to that mid-80s kind of capacity utilization or whether further shrinkage in the business is needed?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I think we'll talk a little bit about that and recap some of those numbers at CAGNY. We are very, very pleased with the Global Supply Chain Transformation. Our operations folks have done a really fabulous job in what is a very complex and large proj
componenttext: Eric, I think we'll talk a little bit about that and recap some of those numbers at CAGNY. We are very, very pleased with the Global Supply Chain Transformation. Our operations folks have done a really fabulous job in what is a very complex and large project, the largest one in the company's history. And it has gone very smoothly and without a hiccup. And you see the improvements in our balance sheet and working capital numbers  are very, very strong. And that's largely part of the footprint and the improvements in the operations. We'll continue to look at our cost structure. We are now in a position in 2010 to look at how we supply the new supply chain, if you will. So we really focused in '08 and '09 on the manufacturing footprint, and that now leaves us with a number of opportunities as we go into 2010 and '11 in terms of how to supply into it in terms of procurement, and in then, how also how to deliver out of it with transportation, warehousing and logistics improvements. And we're very focused on those improvements here in 2010 and '11, but we're always going to constantly look at capacity utilization in our network to make sure it's optimized. And I think we'll have a little bit more just to kind of share some of the numbers with you post Global Supply Chain Transformation at CAGNY.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the meantime, could you give us an estimate as to what you average in terms of capacity utilization for '09? I know that point-in-time estimates for year end are skewed by seasonal factors...
componenttext: In the meantime, could you give us an estimate as to what you average in terms of capacity utilization for '09? I know that point-in-time estimates for year end are skewed by seasonal factors...

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, I think we'll cover that in a couple of weeks.
componenttext: Yes, Eric, I think we'll cover that in a couple of weeks.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I ask about -- looking out into 2010, I think somebody else raised the question of premium strategy. I'm assuming that at some point, hopefully, the economy will start to recover. And I guess for 2009, the focus was very much on, I guess, the non-prem
componenttext: Can I ask about -- looking out into 2010, I think somebody else raised the question of premium strategy. I'm assuming that at some point, hopefully, the economy will start to recover. And I guess for 2009, the focus was very much on, I guess, the non-premium part of the market. Do you anticipate that you'll have a big push to get back into that premium segment? Or do you think you're really going to focus on the core non-premium part of the portfolio?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is -- well, the first thing is I hope you're right that the consumer and the economy get better in 2010. So that's the first thing. What we did focus on in '08 and '09 was really on our mainstream core brands, where consumers were looking for c
componenttext: The answer is -- well, the first thing is I hope you're right that the consumer and the economy get better in 2010. So that's the first thing. What we did focus on in '08 and '09 was really on our mainstream core brands, where consumers were looking for continued value with great brands. So that was something that we were able to provide them and talk to them about specifically through advertising and good merchandising. We continue to support Hershey's Bliss. We supported it strongly in year two in 2009. We'll support it again strongly in year three in 2010. So in that trade up space, we feel very good about how Bliss is performing. And so when you talk about mainstream and trade up, we have fairly well defined those strategies. We obviously are -- while we are not launching anything in the premium space right now, we don't think it's appropriate, that doesn't mean that we're not working on that within our innovation pipeline. And when you think about the entire year 2010, one of the drivers for us in terms of improving our volume is our new products program in 2010 will be stronger than what we had in 2009. That's not to say it's going to be in the premium space, but it will be stronger overall. So we're readying for when the market returns and premium might become a part of that, but we don't have anything that I'd specifically talk about right now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And real quickly, did you give a dollar number for how many millions of  dollar increase in commodity cost that might be in 2010?
componenttext: And real quickly, did you give a dollar number for how many millions of  dollar increase in commodity cost that might be in 2010?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we didn't. Last year, we gave one, given the year-on-year increase. It's not nearly as large of an increase this year. And just given where the commodities market have been, they've just been more similar to last year. Certainly, there are input cost
componenttext: No, we didn't. Last year, we gave one, given the year-on-year increase. It's not nearly as large of an increase this year. And just given where the commodities market have been, they've just been more similar to last year. Certainly, there are input cost increases in 2010. We just didn't put a number on it like last year because of different order magnitude.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm still struggling to reconcile the sales number in the fourth quarter with sort of price, volume and discontinued items. So if I look at your reported sales growth of 2.2%, one point of that was currency. So underlying up 1.2% x currency, you s
componenttext: I guess I'm still struggling to reconcile the sales number in the fourth quarter with sort of price, volume and discontinued items. So if I look at your reported sales growth of 2.2%, one point of that was currency. So underlying up 1.2% x currency, you said pricing was up 7%,  8% in the quarter, and then the discontinued items were about two points of a drag? I'm getting to kind of an underlying volume go down about 4%. Does that math work? Or is there bigger drag in terms of the discontinued items?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well there's base volume declines, which as we said were low-single digits. There is a seasonal shift, which accounts for roughly a point or so of sales. And then there's the discontinued items, which is not only the trades of Starbucks and Cacao Reserve,
componenttext: Well there's base volume declines, which as we said were low-single digits. There is a seasonal shift, which accounts for roughly a point or so of sales. And then there's the discontinued items, which is not only the trades of Starbucks and Cacao Reserve, but it's also -- we had an On-line Gifting business that was in our numbers in 2008 that was not in the numbers in 2009.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you think about the price -- the increases in the fourth quarter, it looked like,  clearly, in the third quarter was up double digit and it slowed to 7%, 8%, and the base volume response when you think about the sequential improvement, certainly, you s
componenttext: If you think about the price -- the increases in the fourth quarter, it looked like,  clearly, in the third quarter was up double digit and it slowed to 7%, 8%, and the base volume response when you think about the sequential improvement, certainly, you saw that improvement. But relative to the pricing moderating, I'm not sure if you saw the kind of the sequential improvement as much as you would've liked to have seen. So is this still kind of in line with what you would've expected as pricing moderated, that you would see a more moderate volume decline? And then my second question is just in terms of the C-store category. I think the category in the fourth quarter was up 2.3%, which seems to be somewhat slower than the other channels. So I'm wondering if you can just talk about what's going on in that channel.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Judy, with respect to pricing and conversion in the fourth quarter and throughout the year 2009, as I said, the marketplace behaved somewhat pretty much as we would expect. We certainly had stronger conversion in the first half of the year than we would'v
componenttext: Judy, with respect to pricing and conversion in the fourth quarter and throughout the year 2009, as I said, the marketplace behaved somewhat pretty much as we would expect. We certainly had stronger conversion in the first half of the year than we would've modeled, but we were pretty much on model in the back half of the year. So we're right about where we would have expected to be on the pricing and the conversion. With respect to convenience stores, obviously, the early part of 2009 had a much stronger pricing component in it. We were very pleased with our chocolate and non-chocolate takeaway in convenience channels throughout the fourth quarter. We underperformed on gum, and that kind of dragged our takeaway down somewhat. Overall, we were up in a reasonable way in the fourth quarter. We feel very good about programming going forward in the convenience class of trade for 2010. So we would've expected, as the price increases kind of got normalized, and we were lapping like increases that the convenience channel would slow a bit in the fourth quarter, and it did.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Bert, just in terms of the gross margin expansion in 2010 that you're expecting, is it on top of the 2009 number that did include some of the LIFO gain in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And then Bert, just in terms of the gross margin expansion in 2010 that you're expecting, is it on top of the 2009 number that did include some of the LIFO gain in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, it is on top of the LIFO gain, so we're not excluding that. I mentioned non-recurring because it doesn't happen frequently. And it was really primarily, we use LIFO accounting. And as we've reduced our inventories as part of the Supply Chain Tr
componenttext: Well, yes, it is on top of the LIFO gain, so we're not excluding that. I mentioned non-recurring because it doesn't happen frequently. And it was really primarily, we use LIFO accounting. And as we've reduced our inventories as part of the Supply Chain Transformation and working capital initiatives, we got that. So, yes, it doesn't exclude that. It's incremental to that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you said it was about 100 basis points of a benefit in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And you said it was about 100 basis points of a benefit in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you quantify the cost related to the Cadbury transaction with the advisory fee that you paid out in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And can you quantify the cost related to the Cadbury transaction with the advisory fee that you paid out in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mentioned that they were about equal to the LIFO.
componenttext: Yes, I mentioned that they were about equal to the LIFO.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Lazar with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Lazar with Barclays Capital.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, from perspective of your earnings guidance for 2010, I'm assuming that does not necessarily contemplate what you could do one way or another with the cash that has come up  throughout the call?
componenttext: One, from perspective of your earnings guidance for 2010, I'm assuming that does not necessarily contemplate what you could do one way or another with the cash that has come up  throughout the call?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had mentioned last call, Dave, I think that you were going to increase trade spends here and there just to kind of, I think it was ease consumers' transition to some of the new higher promoted price points. And given that it didn't necessarily come up
componenttext: You had mentioned last call, Dave, I think that you were going to increase trade spends here and there just to kind of, I think it was ease consumers' transition to some of the new higher promoted price points. And given that it didn't necessarily come up specifically on the call, I assume there's nothing really out of the ordinary with that, and you didn't need maybe more than you assumed or less than you assumed. How did that process go?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Andrew, when we talked about the price increases and trying to get to higher promoted price points, which is what we wanted to do within our business, I think that went about as we would've expected. Within the direct trade spending, obviously,
componenttext: Actually, Andrew, when we talked about the price increases and trying to get to higher promoted price points, which is what we wanted to do within our business, I think that went about as we would've expected. Within the direct trade spending, obviously, our spend is much more around getting location and merchandising and less about price reduction. And I guess the only abnormal thing I would say, or not abnormal, I guess it's going to become normal, in 2009 was the return of couponing as a large part of the mix. Couponing was up pretty close to 30% across most of the categories in 2009. And so I think that's one of the elements of the mix that, given where the consumer mindset is right now, would be about the only significant change I would point to in '09.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, I think you've said you'll get into a lot more detail on sort of the productivity opportunity and what have you at CAGNY. I guess I'm trying to get a sense of the best we can do is you benchmark kind of where you're at in terms of yo
componenttext: And then just lastly, I think you've said you'll get into a lot more detail on sort of the productivity opportunity and what have you at CAGNY. I guess I'm trying to get a sense of the best we can do is you benchmark kind of where you're at in terms of your supply chain numbers in '09 and assumption on your ongoing kind of productivity. It would seem like you still have some room if you benchmark you against peers. And obviously, a lot of your peers have been more recently ramping up their productivity efforts as well, given the environment. So I'm trying to get a sense of as you get into this at CAGNY, can you say that these are programs that will be more ongoing in nature? Meaning, things for which the costs you'll absorb in the P&L as you go rather than necessarily incremental sort of charges like we saw as part of the Supply Chain program?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we'll talk about is, as I said, sourcing and procurement opportunities, logistics and supply chain opportunities. And then also, as we look in the longer term, the way we use sales technology and work with retail partners, there's an opp
componenttext: Yes, I think what we'll talk about is, as I said, sourcing and procurement opportunities, logistics and supply chain opportunities. And then also, as we look in the longer term, the way we use sales technology and work with retail partners, there's an opportunity for us to be much more efficient. And that's one of the advantages of having a dedicated direct sales force. So we'll talk about those as all of those levers as ongoing productivity. We at minimum obviously want to offset inflation. And we feel pretty good that we've got programs that can do better than that into the future.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just had some just three quick follow-ups, first would be are there any residual Cadbury expenses that you take in Q1? Or is that all in Q4?
componenttext: Just had some just three quick follow-ups, first would be are there any residual Cadbury expenses that you take in Q1? Or is that all in Q4?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's very little in Q1, and that's built into our 2010 forecast.
componenttext: There's very little in Q1, and that's built into our 2010 forecast.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I could also ask about, you mentioned early on about International growth over the last five years. Could you give us a feel for how that performed in 2009, excluding currency of course?
componenttext: And then if I could also ask about, you mentioned early on about International growth over the last five years. Could you give us a feel for how that performed in 2009, excluding currency of course?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in 2009, you're quite right, currency was quite a big impact, and it was a drag for the first three quarters. But if you exclude currency, we had growth in all of our markets, organic growth in all of our markets, including or excluding, if you want,
componenttext: Yes, in 2009, you're quite right, currency was quite a big impact, and it was a drag for the first three quarters. But if you exclude currency, we had growth in all of our markets, organic growth in all of our markets, including or excluding, if you want, the Van Houten business that we acquired last January.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But could you give like a composite number, like was the International growth up -- I guess to what percentage of your total sales or give us some feel for that?
componenttext: But could you give like a composite number, like was the International growth up -- I guess to what percentage of your total sales or give us some feel for that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my final question is regarding your market share. Now you had a number of unique factors in this quarter, like Cacao Reserve and Starbucks that were kind of weighing on your volumes. So excluding that, it looks like your market share would've bee
componenttext: And then my final question is regarding your market share. Now you had a number of unique factors in this quarter, like Cacao Reserve and Starbucks that were kind of weighing on your volumes. So excluding that, it looks like your market share would've been down a little bit, maybe flat. Is that a good number, you believe, for the fourth quarter, I'm talking here?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I guess I would say I wouldn't necessarily want to get into decomposing the building blocks by brand or by event. We expected that we would lose share in the fourth quarter. It was largely due to premium and drug. We lost 1.9 share points in the
componenttext: Actually, I guess I would say I wouldn't necessarily want to get into decomposing the building blocks by brand or by event. We expected that we would lose share in the fourth quarter. It was largely due to premium and drug. We lost 1.9 share points in the drug class of trade, which is a pretty meaningful class of trade for us in the fourth quarter. Those were the two biggest drivers. I don't think you can really decompose and say it's due to a brand or it's due to something. It really is those two events. Overall, we gained a tenth of a share point FDMxC in 2009. We think that with everything, all of the moving parts in the marketplace that that's a reasonable performance, and we would expect to be able to continue that in 2010.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick one, in terms of the guidance or the cadence you've given in terms of helping modeling out profits and gross margins, it sounds like it's kind of front-half loaded, with pricing and cost savings flowing through more in the first half of the
componenttext: Just one quick one, in terms of the guidance or the cadence you've given in terms of helping modeling out profits and gross margins, it sounds like it's kind of front-half loaded, with pricing and cost savings flowing through more in the first half of the year than the second half. Is your expectation for cost inflation that it will be higher in the second half than the first half? Or should we just think about it as being kind of consistent across the year?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the way we're looking at it right now is we've built all of our expectations into our standard cost. And as a result, we use standard, obviously, as the way we reflect our gross margins. So it's evenly spread throughout the quarters. The one point th
componenttext: Yes, the way we're looking at it right now is we've built all of our expectations into our standard cost. And as a result, we use standard, obviously, as the way we reflect our gross margins. So it's evenly spread throughout the quarters. The one point that I would say is dairy. Obviously, we've made certain assumptions around dairy, and we think that, that will increase some, but not spike to the levels that we saw in 2008 when there was drought in Australia and New Zealand and things like that, that made the front page [ph](01:18:27).  And then the Global Supply Chain Transformation, you've already mentioned, which yes, we've entered the program, there are still some incremental benefits. And by the time you get to around midyear, that equalizes.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if I were to understand, if there's any variability to the standard cost forecast in 2010, it's really going to be dairy that would drive it, not the other inputs?
componenttext: So if I were to understand, if there's any variability to the standard cost forecast in 2010, it's really going to be dairy that would drive it, not the other inputs?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I would say that, that there could be, obviously, pricing that occurs in commodity variability. But yes, dairy certainly is the one that has the most potential to impact. The other element, again, that we mentioned which aids the first half is that t
componenttext: Well I would say that, that there could be, obviously, pricing that occurs in commodity variability. But yes, dairy certainly is the one that has the most potential to impact. The other element, again, that we mentioned which aids the first half is that the pricing which remains built into the P&L on Valentine's and particularly Easter, because we ship a lot of Valentine in the fourth quarter, is certainly front-end loaded.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to have one quick question about mix. I understand the premium category is slowing down. Are there opportunities within your margins to actually move up the mix either between, like, single serve? Or is it getting -- reducing the bags or is th
componenttext: I just want to have one quick question about mix. I understand the premium category is slowing down. Are there opportunities within your margins to actually move up the mix either between, like, single serve? Or is it getting -- reducing the bags or is there a channel shift? Anywhere that you think that there's a mix component outside of pure cost savings and supply chain in this environment? And can you talk about that a little bit?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there always are opportunities, and we actually think very much about that with respect to our planning. When we plan out customer plans and we plan out against promoting pack size, et cetera, we look at mix continuously. I think that continuing to g
componenttext: Yes, there always are opportunities, and we actually think very much about that with respect to our planning. When we plan out customer plans and we plan out against promoting pack size, et cetera, we look at mix continuously. I think that continuing to grow in convenience, our King Size business continuing to grow, those are things that are very positive and favorable with respect to mix. And I think when you look at 2010 versus 2009, there isn't any real significant change in the portfolio we expect to sell that would tell you we'll have a significant mix shift in 2010. But it is something that we are always working towards to make sure that we take advantage of either more profitable customers and/or classes of trade.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Dreyer with Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Dreyer with Gabelli & Company.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In looking at Cadbury, did that change from a management or Board perspective the level of leverage that you'd be comfortable with as a company? And also, there were some talk about being open to M&A, how does this change your fine tuning on thoughts on g
componenttext: In looking at Cadbury, did that change from a management or Board perspective the level of leverage that you'd be comfortable with as a company? And also, there were some talk about being open to M&A, how does this change your fine tuning on thoughts on globalization strategy, whether future M&A with common existing markets, international markets or domestically?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think we said in the past in terms of international markets, and it's not unlike a lot of other organizations. We certainly have a greater focus on emerging markets. If you see where we've gone in the past, we've had a good Mexican business for
componenttext: I mean, I think we said in the past in terms of international markets, and it's not unlike a lot of other organizations. We certainly have a greater focus on emerging markets. If you see where we've gone in the past, we've had a good Mexican business for quite some time. We entered into a joint venture in Brazil, same in India. We're active in a manufacturing JV in China. And there are other markets that are interesting to us. I think we said in the past that in terms of the European market, it's more mature, perhaps more difficult to get into. So emerging market because of the faster growth rates and the living standards just increasing this. So that continues to be our focus. In terms of do we have a different perspective on leverage, I think not. I mean, we've always said that we very much value the A rating that we have. As you would expect, we did an awful lot of modeling and discussions around different leverage levels. But philosophically, we intend to have a strong balance sheet. And the whole capital structure discussion really is a Board-level discussion, which the Board has its own awful lot of input into. So I don't think it has changed the way we approach it.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Palmer with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Palmer with UBS.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Hershey results remind me a little bit I guess it was over a decade ago when the beer industry and its players started to accept that low volume and perhaps stable per capita consumption was the reality for a long time. And pricing by the large player
componenttext: The Hershey results remind me a little bit I guess it was over a decade ago when the beer industry and its players started to accept that low volume and perhaps stable per capita consumption was the reality for a long time. And pricing by the large players became the repeating driver of the top line, and CapEx was lower than depreciation for a long time, driving above-average free cash flow. It somewhat looks like Hershey today. Is it possible that even after the consumer gets its feet under it that the U.S. chocolate players accept that long-term per capita increase in consumption are simply not going to be realistic long term? And that we could be seeing the beginning of a period which price increases with heavy reinvestment in advertising is a virtuous cycle and a healthy earnings driver for perhaps several years?

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I think what I would tell you is that the category has consistently grown 3% to 4% for many, many years. The drivers are different depending on the set of circumstances. Some years, it's price increases. Some years, it's volume from innovation. Som
componenttext: David, I think what I would tell you is that the category has consistently grown 3% to 4% for many, many years. The drivers are different depending on the set of circumstances. Some years, it's price increases. Some years, it's volume from innovation. Some years, it's base volume . Other years, it's been mix in terms of some of the shifting between either gum and mint and chocolate. But the category has been fairly consistent and robust. In a difficult economic time, it actually was even better than historical last year. This year, it happened to be driven by relative increases in price. We're very pleased that the conversion has been better. Unit conversion has been stronger than what the pricing models would've told us. As we continue to look at our business going forward, we view this as a very dynamic on-trend category. It's an advantaged category, and we're going to make the appropriate investments in it to drive growth here. I don't view it as a category that's doesn't have the capability to continue to be advantaged and drive good growth for us into the future. Pricing actions in 2008/'09 were necessary, given the commodity cost structure that we encountered. And that happens from time to time in this business, but it's not a signal that the only growth in this category can come from pricing.

headline: Hershey Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
