headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're obviously pleased with our cash flow. And we have cash on the balance sheet now, which would've been true last year where we were still in the current paper market. In terms of our bond maturity, we do have a bond maturing next year, and that's
componenttext: Yes, we're obviously pleased with our cash flow. And we have cash on the balance sheet now, which would've been true last year where we were still in the current paper market. In terms of our bond maturity, we do have a bond maturing next year, and that's in 2011. And so obviously, we're already thinking about that, given that it's already moved from long-term to short-term position on the balance sheet. Cash flow continues to be good. And I already mentioned, we're about current on our share repurchase program, with respect to replenishment of stock options. The question that always comes up, obviously, is around buyback and then maybe what you're insinuating is the discussion that we seriously had with the board, and we continue to have that. And we have other options in terms of  cash use. So we're pleased with where we are from a cash flow perspective, working capital and otherwise, strong gross margin growth. And we'll take the appropriate action going forward.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question, Alexia Howard, Morgan Stanley. [Bernstein]
componenttext: Your next question, Alexia Howard, Morgan Stanley. [Bernstein]

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alexia Howard, from Bernstein here. I'd like to hear little bit more in China and India. I know that you talked a little bit about it earlier on. Are you able to actually comment on what percentage of sales those two markets are expected to contribute in
componenttext: Alexia Howard, from Bernstein here. I'd like to hear little bit more in China and India. I know that you talked a little bit about it earlier on. Are you able to actually comment on what percentage of sales those two markets are expected to contribute in 2010? And what kind of less are you getting on the quarterly numbers, in terms of how much is contributing to sales growth year-on-year? And maybe just more broadly or qualitatively, what lessons have you learned and what do you see as the biggest opportunities in those two markets?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we have made some investments outside of the U.S. pretty broadly. Asia is a place where we are investing. We've invested in some go-to-market capabilities with respect to the way we're distributing and selling in both India and China. I think
componenttext:
Yes, I think we have made some investments outside of the U.S. pretty broadly. Asia is a place where we are investing. We've invested in some go-to-market capabilities with respect to the way we're distributing and selling in both India and China. I think that the international growth rates added, maybe, let's call it 100 basis points of the growth in the quarter to our growth rates. Again, that's across the board. The third quarter in China particularly is a seasonally light quarter because we ramped up for the Chinese New Year, which is in the early part of next year. And that ramp up really starts in September on. So there's not a lot of activity sales-wise in China. 
In the third quarter, we spent some time building out distribution. We will support our brand in China in the fourth quarter, when I talk about the incremental advertising spending that we're having in the fourth quarter. China is one of the places where we are certainly adding some sampling and some support behind our brand. And as I think about our plans for 2011 on a go-forward basis, we would expect that the non-U.S. businesses would be added to the top line growth rate for next year as well.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question, Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question, Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just sort of your initial outlook for 2011, you're going to have a very tough comps against 2010 on the top line. So what it is in particular that's giving you the confidence that you can still sustain what will be pretty robust top line growth next year?
componenttext: Just sort of your initial outlook for 2011, you're going to have a very tough comps against 2010 on the top line. So what it is in particular that's giving you the confidence that you can still sustain what will be pretty robust top line growth next year? Is it the advertising level, the promotion or the work you're doing around some of the Mounds and Almond Joy-type brands? What is it that's driving that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A combination of things, in the U.S. in particular. Our innovation, we launched Kisses earlier this year and that's done very well. But remember, we have the Hershey's Drops and the Reese's Mini's that will ship in December, and so that innovation that be
componenttext: A combination of things, in the U.S. in particular. Our innovation, we launched Kisses earlier this year and that's done very well. But remember, we have the Hershey's Drops and the Reese's Mini's that will ship in December, and so that innovation that becomes additive for us next year. We have other innovation in our pipeline for 2011 that we feel very good about. And so that will be an additive component for us next year. We are advertising and added some GRPs across the number of brands this year. We are in the fourth quarter, increasing the GRP levels on Mounds and Almond Joy and York. And then, we're were adding some advertising support across PayDay and Hershey's Syrup for the first time since 2001. So that will have to -- we think that the impression of the brand, and then we're also continuing to look at better sales force execution. And we're gaining some distribution points in the communities class of trade, as we brought on extra resources this year. So we have a number of additive leverage that we've invested in this year. And we'll start to test Insights Driven Performance, which we are investing in here pretty significantly in the back half of the year. It will be more on a pilot form next year. We think it will help us as we get set up for the last part of '11 and into 2012.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the investments in the International business. Is there any chance you can give us just a little bit on how dilutive you think investment in international is going to be for the next couple of years? And then also, your market share gai
componenttext: Can you talk about the investments in the International business. Is there any chance you can give us just a little bit on how dilutive you think investment in international is going to be for the next couple of years? And then also, your market share gains are great this year. But they are slowing. And yet, you're dialing up advertising, and you have a huge increase this year in advertising. Why wouldn't these gains be more sustainable? Or do you just think the competition is having a go-at-it in the third quarter, and now you're going to launch your new products and that will kind of reverse it the other way again, as we head into the next couple of quarters.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good questions, Rob. I'll probably just give you some perspective. On a year-to-date basis, FDMxC W, so that's kind of 80% of the universe. So I'm talking year-to-date. Our takeaway is up 4.7%. So that's barely solid nine months through '10 to take away.
componenttext:
Good questions, Rob. I'll probably just give you some perspective. On a year-to-date basis, FDMxC W, so that's kind of 80% of the universe. So I'm talking year-to-date. Our takeaway is up 4.7%. So that's barely solid nine months through '10 to take away. And if you look at the third quarter takeaway, we were up roughly 3.5%. So our FDMxC W takeaway was 3.5%, and we held share within that 3.5%. So we still are seeing 3.5%, pick a number, 3.5%, 4.5% category in terms of takeaway growth. So good numbers. Within the third quarter, we were sequentially much better in the drug class trade for the first time in the number of quarters. We actually gained share in drug. And we talked about 3.2% takeaway and a 60 basis point gain in share in drug. And we were very pleased with the sequential improvement in the mass retailers. And in convenience, we held and gained a little bit of share, as well in the quarter. Where we lost share, the one area which I talked about, was we lost the last half of a share point in food, off of the 2.5% takeaway growth. And that's really where we lost some merchandising in the third quarter. We had talked about some new items that some of the other chocolate competitors were coming with in the third quarter. We lost some merchandising in food. And we also moved away from a promoted price point on one of our price that we didn't like particularly much in food that wasn't as profitable for us. 
So when I we think about the business overall in the third quarter, still a good category growth rate, although a little bit more of shared [indiscernible] remember, our innovation comes in the fourth quarter in the form of Reese's Mini's and Hershey's Drops. So overall, the category is still growing very well. We feel very good about it. We've got volume returns in this category, and I think the growth rates are pretty good. So the advertising it's working on the brands, we're putting in. And then we significantly added some advertising spending. We've been fortunate to be performing pretty well in the last few years within the U.S. business. And as that U.S. business has performed well, we've taken advantage of opportunity to go up and take the demand landscape, learning that worked so well for us in the U.S. And we used that learning in Canada, Mexico, China for example, and what we're now doing is accelerating our investments in go-to-market capabilities, as well as in brand building in those markets. So we've absorbed that type of ramp-up in spending in the international markets in our results for the last two years. And when we talk about next year, we also see similar kinds of investments in international within the long term, 6% to 8% number that we gave you. So we're able to continue to grow our earnings base and still do those international investments.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You don't want to give us a number on the dilution effect?
componenttext: You don't want to give us a number on the dilution effect?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, I think in Bert's remarks we said it, that operating income -- the only market outside the U.S. where we saw operating income growth was in Canada. We had operating income declines in the rest of the market. So it clearly has the dilutiv
componenttext: Just to be clear, I think in Bert's remarks we said it, that operating income -- the only market outside the U.S. where we saw operating income growth was in Canada. We had operating income declines in the rest of the market. So it clearly has the dilutive effect for us. But we are, as I said, we've been able to absorb that in our core businesses in the U.S., and in particularly, in Canada with the investment levels. And we see ourselves able to do that again in the next year and into the long term as we talk about that 6% to 8%.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow, BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow, BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the timing between advertising spending and the incremental sales growth? What I'm trying to get a sense of is, when Hershey's spend $1 of advertising, how do you assess or how do you expect the incremental sales growth? And just the ti
componenttext: Can you talk about the timing between advertising spending and the incremental sales growth? What I'm trying to get a sense of is, when Hershey's spend $1 of advertising, how do you assess or how do you expect the incremental sales growth? And just the timing of how that works? You're spending a lot of advertising and I would expect it to kind of have an implication for 2011. So if you can just bridge that a little bit, that'd be helpful.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, and I think we've mentioned this before, we take a pretty disciplined approach in terms of our ad spending. And so we keep a keen eye on how we think about ROI. Clearly, brands with scale are the ones that will give you the better ROI. So you
componenttext:
I would say, and I think we've mentioned this before, we take a pretty disciplined approach in terms of our ad spending. And so we keep a keen eye on how we think about ROI. Clearly, brands with scale are the ones that will give you the better ROI. So you're right, there's certainly is a lag effect in terms of advertising spend today and brand building in consumer's minds and purchases in the future. 
So as we think about fourth quarter spend in particular, we do expect them, and we have our own internal calculations. I've had that impact in the first couple of quarters of next year. And certainly, there's a positive correlation. We look at those ROIs on a brand basis, on a monthly basis as well. So it's not something that we do at long intervals. We keep a constant review of what that ad spend is. When Dave mentioned Syrup and PayDay, which we haven't had on air since 2009. Certainly, there was a lot of analytical and work done around that -- our 2001, rather, a lot of analytical work beyond that to determine whether those were right two brands put on air and at what levels. 
So the only thing that I would add to that, which is a different dynamic, is in international markets, ROI certainly are lower. And that gets back to the scale comment that I meant earlier, the larger the brand, the greater lift you're going to get simply based on that scale. And so in the international market, it's more about long-term brand building. But in the U.S., their payoffs are much more immediate. And they normally, as we think of it, come in the next couple of quarters.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: How many more brands? And I know you won't tell me which ones. But how many more brands do you have that have significant underinvestment similar like the PayDay or Syrup? It sounds like, are you coming to the end of that? And then, are going to move to t
componenttext: How many more brands? And I know you won't tell me which ones. But how many more brands do you have that have significant underinvestment similar like the PayDay or Syrup? It sounds like, are you coming to the end of that? And then, are going to move to the international? Or is there still some runway in terms of the non-chocolate confectionery side?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We never say we're come to the end. That sounds like a -- let me rephrase that . We've gotten good investment on the majority of the brands that we would expect to see good lifts. We've been able to accelerate some of them. We certainly were able to do Mo
componenttext:
We never say we're come to the end. That sounds like a -- let me rephrase that . We've gotten good investment on the majority of the brands that we would expect to see good lifts. We've been able to accelerate some of them. We certainly were able to do Mounds, Almond Joy and York earlier this year based on the successes that we had back in 2009. And we're able to do PayDay and Hershey's Syrup a little bit earlier than we would've expected. So maybe another brand or so. 
And in with respect to international, in the last two years, we've already made those investments. I think Bert mentioned the number was about 65% or so increase in ad spending in the international markets outside the U.S. in the third quarter. So that's already in our numbers. And so when you see the increases in advertising as we kind of roll through the year, what we are doing is really accelerating some of the strategic plan work that we're doing, with respect to the demand landscape work that we've shared with you to get some of the brands where we think we can activate some pretty smartly because they have some unique characteristics. And then, in the international markets, I think we're applying some of the really good learnings from the U.S. and doing it a little quicker than I think we would have expected we would've gotten to it.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Judy Hong, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Judy Hong, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason English, here. The outlook and how you keep the momentum going, inflation is obviously a concern, I think you guys are calling it out in your press release. You mentioned as a potential headwind for next year. As you lay out guidance here, what degr
componenttext: Jason English, here. The outlook and how you keep the momentum going, inflation is obviously a concern, I think you guys are calling it out in your press release. You mentioned as a potential headwind for next year. As you lay out guidance here, what degree of inflationary you guys contemplating within that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of our cost basket, and you're right, we're certainly anticipating just based on our internal estimates and the visibility that we have for next year already. We certainly expect that commodity, as an example, will be ramping up next year in
componenttext: Yes, in terms of our cost basket, and you're right, we're certainly anticipating just based on our internal estimates and the visibility that we have for next year already. We certainly expect that commodity, as an example, will be ramping up next year in terms of cost. We've done awful lot of productivity programs behind providing all set there. And in terms of gross margin, we don't expect to repeat that type of performance that we had this year in a more benign commodity environment. So we're continuously looking for ways to offset that inflation within the manufacturing space. But there's no doubt that inflation is a headwind next year compared to this year. We have it built into how we think about the top line and bottom line. And we still believe we have leverage in the P&L to be able to achieve within that 6% to 8%. But the composition of next year's cost basket is more inflated than this year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it possible for you guys to quantify what you're thinking in terms of range? And you mentioned that you're also thinking about the impact on top line. Can I interpret that to mean that you're contemplating some pricing moves to help you mitigate this?
componenttext: Is it possible for you guys to quantify what you're thinking in terms of range? And you mentioned that you're also thinking about the impact on top line. Can I interpret that to mean that you're contemplating some pricing moves to help you mitigate this?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not going to comment on pricing at all. I think with prepared comments we're really around the input cost in terms of inflation. And our cost basket is frankly a bit different since some of the other folks in the food space were bigger buyers of coc
componenttext: We're not going to comment on pricing at all. I think with prepared comments we're really around the input cost in terms of inflation. And our cost basket is frankly a bit different since some of the other folks in the food space were bigger buyers of cocoa and sugar and dairies, and we're not in the green complex as much as others. But I'm not sure our inflation assumptions which would be translated before you. For competitor reasons, we're not going to get into that kind of a blow-by-blow, commodity by commodity. We do expect that our basket will be higher overall. But we have very good productivity in place to offset some of that. And we think that's how we're planning our business for 2011.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think through the first half of the year, you mentioned that the trade was running below initial expectations. Has that changed and do you see a need to see bring more trades spent in the market?
componenttext: I think through the first half of the year, you mentioned that the trade was running below initial expectations. Has that changed and do you see a need to see bring more trades spent in the market?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The rate in the third quarter was about flat versus the prior year's rate. In the first half of the year, it's actually been a little bit favorable on a rate basis. And what we have gotten in the second quarter call, I think we said that would likely abat
componenttext: The rate in the third quarter was about flat versus the prior year's rate. In the first half of the year, it's actually been a little bit favorable on a rate basis. And what we have gotten in the second quarter call, I think we said that would likely abate if we got the back half. And so the rate is roughly in line with what it was a year ago. And again, I think when you see retailers will choose what price points they want to run, particularly the seasonal events that. So far what we've seen year-over-year on Halloween in the marketplace is the pricing is roughly equivalent on a promoted basis, as it was year ago.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, the back half is always a little bit more, if you want to call it, intense because it has a higher seasonal component. But we're not seeing anything that's a lot different than what we anticipated.
componenttext: I mean, the back half is always a little bit more, if you want to call it, intense because it has a higher seasonal component. But we're not seeing anything that's a lot different than what we anticipated.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar, Barclays Capital.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar, Barclays Capital.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow up a little bit for the one you just had. I guess, some food companies, when do you think about their long-term sort of top and bottom line growth algorithm, they'll say our intent over time is to either offset inflation through pricin
componenttext: Just a quick follow up a little bit for the one you just had. I guess, some food companies, when do you think about their long-term sort of top and bottom line growth algorithm, they'll say our intent over time is to either offset inflation through pricing, stuffs that we have -- productivity to fund the marketing and what not to drive the top line. Or we attempt to offset inflation through a combination of pricing and cost base or what have you. And I don't know, I apologize but I just can't remember, have you gotten that granular around your long-term growth and algorithm? And ultimately, how you anticipate handling inflation over time?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have not actually given that level of specificity. And I think one of the reasons we're a little bit more cautious about giving that much specific detail is, we're the only ones in the confection space who are giving certain public pronouncements. And
componenttext:
We have not actually given that level of specificity. And I think one of the reasons we're a little bit more cautious about giving that much specific detail is, we're the only ones in the confection space who are giving certain public pronouncements. And competitively, we'd like to keep our particular commodity strategies a little bit more closer to the depth. I think in principle, Andrew, what you're seeing is absolutely right. Over time, you would like to offset and pass on the appropriate increase in your cost basket. We have been particularly aggressive, I think, within our supply chain, obviously, with the Global Supply Chain Transformation project that we completed, where we closed seven  facilities and built the new one in Monterrey, Mexico. We have what we're calling Project Next Century where we're working very hard to continue to improve the efficiencies of our bakeries -- of our plant here in Hershey, rebuilding a new facility and then invest a couple of hundred million dollars here in our whole market. 
So we look at those productivity program, as well as just better efficiency in the business by focusing on the core to have given us the flexibility to meet the issues within our cost basket, as well as our investment needs. But on a go-forward basis, I think in principle, I would say, we would like to be able to deal with input pressures and eventually be able to pass those along to the consumers as appropriate. But I think the other thing that's somewhat unique about the category is that it's so promotionally intensive and some of much of it was in the merchandising it's really less about list pricing and how come consumers think about promoted price points over time. And those are a little harder to move. They tend to move in bigger increments than simple list prices. So there's an algorithm for us that maybe a little bit more difficult to implement because of the significant portion of our business, which is seasonal and merchandise in that way. We have historically, as a category, tended to move in bigger increments on promoted prices. And then maybe you'd see in other categories. But we do, over time expect that we'd like to pass on those kinds of costs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do recall that in the last one that you took a while back, you did move the promoted price point. And the move in that price was much more dramatic in whatever it was, 20% for 25% kind of move.
componenttext: I do recall that in the last one that you took a while back, you did move the promoted price point. And the move in that price was much more dramatic in whatever it was, 20% for 25% kind of move.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That 20% or 25% is correct.
componenttext: That 20% or 25% is correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just kind of keeping on that same theme, but not to beat a dead horse. The last time the industry or the category raised prices so aggressively, there was kind of I'd say more of elasticity than maybe what is initially expected. And I think, Dave
componenttext: I guess, just kind of keeping on that same theme, but not to beat a dead horse. The last time the industry or the category raised prices so aggressively, there was kind of I'd say more of elasticity than maybe what is initially expected. And I think, Dave, you suggested that the premium end of the category is still kind of flattish or not keeping up with the mass part of the business. And so does that kind of suggest to you that putting through a price increase would be met by a fair amount of elasticity, given what you see from the consumer segments within confection?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Eric, let me just clarify my point. If you look at an aggregate of about roughly flat for the year. Those two segments are not contributing on a combined basis. They're not really contributing to category growth. It really still is very much a mai
componenttext:
I think Eric, let me just clarify my point. If you look at an aggregate of about roughly flat for the year. Those two segments are not contributing on a combined basis. They're not really contributing to category growth. It really still is very much a mainstream story. I think when we did take our pricing action that we announced in August of '08 and implemented really in '09 and then it still gets a little bit into early 2010, we did see volumes return a little more quickly than we would've expected from our modeling. So we were very encouraged by that. 
What we all have to continue to monitor is consumer behavior and where consumers are today and they're thinking about value. One of the big beautiful things about our category is it is an approachable luxury and/or indulgence at the time when consumers are looking for that. So the category dynamics right now, as I've said, we've got good growth in the category. It's a very volume-oriented category. And people are playing innovation approach right now in the category. We've looked very good about that. So we think the category growth rates are strong where they are. I don't want to talk very much about forward pricing. I think the one of the other factors is, as you taking a look at pricing, is what's happening around the entire rest of the basket. And I think there seems to be some inflationary pressure. Retailers are talking about it. And it looks like some other folks are also, in other categories are going to do some things. 
So that's also a big factor -- is our prices in any category moving up by themselves or are they moving in context of the entire basket? So all of those things, I think, would impact the way the modeling would work' for us. We clearly model it out constantly. And I think what I would say right now is, we're pretty comfortable with where our businesses and that we've got volume returning. And beyond, I don't think I'll comment any further on anything that's happened in the market.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the last time I heard Hershey talk about getting more aggressive with PayDay. It was kind of towards the end of the growth story. I think you try to position that as a sports kind of bar or something along those lines. And that didn't work. And so
componenttext: I think the last time I heard Hershey talk about getting more aggressive with PayDay. It was kind of towards the end of the growth story. I think you try to position that as a sports kind of bar or something along those lines. And that didn't work. And so, I guess I just point that out in that you do have the new drops and bite-sized type stuff that seems to be working. I mean, is the next move kind of an enrobed product which you don't really have in your, let's say, quiver? As I've said before, I think that the drops and stuff is kind of like a bite-sized M&M type product, and the one thing that you haven't been successful at is putting out something that competes with Snickers or Milky Way or something along those lines.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the reference you make to position PayDay as an energy bar. We have a product that we have that we call PayDay Pro which had higher levels and more grams of protein and if it's not the product we're talking about, what we are talking about here is
componenttext:
I think the reference you make to position PayDay as an energy bar. We have a product that we have that we call PayDay Pro which had higher levels and more grams of protein and if it's not the product we're talking about, what we are talking about here is supporting the PayDay bar itself. We hadn't had advertising on air since 2001. And we think PayDay is uniquely positioned in the demand landscape work that you have in our portfolio, that it doesn't really interact with much else that we have in the portfolio. 
So we think it can be pretty incremental for us. We do think that Hershey's Drops and Reese's Mini's launches will be good launches for us. We're excited about. And we will support them with advertising unique to those items. And we have other innovation that's planned for 2011, which we're not at this point in time going to reveal to you. But again, we are very anchored in the demand landscape in terms of what's incremental to the portfolio and where white spaces in the category. And I think we'll share some more of that when we get into the early part of the year, probably at CAGNY.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You moved and created a new facility in Monterrey, and all you hear out of that city is pretty tough conditions. Is that something to be concerned about? Like is that a facility that you use for the export market or does that come back in here? Or do you
componenttext: You moved and created a new facility in Monterrey, and all you hear out of that city is pretty tough conditions. Is that something to be concerned about? Like is that a facility that you use for the export market or does that come back in here? Or do you have the capacity utilization to meet demand if things get worse there as opposed to better?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The facilities in Monterrey, Mexico, it is producing products for the U.S. market. We have embarked like many of the companies in the Fortune 500 and beyond, on a pretty robust Enterprise Risk Management or ERM program. Supply in sourcing is one of those
componenttext: The facilities in Monterrey, Mexico, it is producing products for the U.S. market. We have embarked like many of the companies in the Fortune 500 and beyond, on a pretty robust Enterprise Risk Management or ERM program. Supply in sourcing is one of those things that's in that. So this is something that we continuously look at, source of supply not just in Monterrey but throughout our network. We have experienced no issues in Monterrey with respect to our manufacturing facility. And we haven't experienced any issues bringing products across the borders, et cetera. As a matter of fact, that project went very well for us. It achieved its milestone. The productivity that we got from that back in '09 and closed up this year is very strong. So we're pleased with how that's gone. It's no different than any other supply situation. You continue to monitor your inventory levels, and it is something that's part of an ERM program we look at, but we are pleased with where we are.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll, Citi Investment.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll, Citi Investment.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On commodity inflation for 2011, Bert, can you just comment on whether or not you feel good about your visibility into the cost structure for 2011 at this juncture?
componenttext: On commodity inflation for 2011, Bert, can you just comment on whether or not you feel good about your visibility into the cost structure for 2011 at this juncture?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, what we said towards at the end of -- or at least what I tried to communicate to you again at the end of my prepared remarks. There certainly is much more commodity inflation. We haven't experienced as much this year as we thought. In the thir
componenttext:
Yes, David, what we said towards at the end of -- or at least what I tried to communicate to you again at the end of my prepared remarks. There certainly is much more commodity inflation. We haven't experienced as much this year as we thought. In the third quarter, and we thought we've had some higher commodities. I mentioned that. It was really had a flat. We did that change starting the fourth quarter starts to move up, and we see that some of that continuing. 
Certainly, at this time of the year, we start to get some reasonable visibility. In terms of next year, we're very focused on being able to say more about that later on. And also, very focused against the productivity programs of which right now, we mentioned the CAGNY programs that starts to deliver even more next year, not just on cost of goods line but also below that. So at the moment, we feel pretty balanced the fact that we expect certainly commodity prices to be higher for next year. And then just put it in perspective, the only comment I made was that this year, our gross margin, as we all know, has really been terrific. We don't expect to see that next year. But right now, where we have reasonable visibility. We've got good. Not just on the cost side but on the savings. So we don't provide an inflation number. And we will provide more color on that the next time we get together. But we're pretty pleased with where we are right now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the productivity savings, you have a number of different programs. And frankly, I don't think you guys ever like give us a summation of it. But when I do it, I think it's approximately about 3% of cost of sales for 2011. Is that about the right number
componenttext: On the productivity savings, you have a number of different programs. And frankly, I don't think you guys ever like give us a summation of it. But when I do it, I think it's approximately about 3% of cost of sales for 2011. Is that about the right number when you add up all the different productivity programs you have going on?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a couple of things, as you mentioned, that are out there. And when we think of continuous improvement is a year on and year out program. It's not a special program, and that's intended to, I think, it was referred to earlier, is intended to a
componenttext: Yes, we have a couple of things, as you mentioned, that are out there. And when we think of continuous improvement is a year on and year out program. It's not a special program, and that's intended to, I think, it was referred to earlier, is intended to a approximately offset our inflation. The program that we unveiled at CAGNY, which focuses more in non-manufacturing productivity and cost savings to procurement, is separate from that. And it's intended to be, at least in 2011 and '12, 2x the normal productivity. So if we think about our continuous improvement being an attempt to offset inflation. And we think we can do approximately 2x that, you would assume that '11 and '12 has a higher level of productivity. And if you exclude, obviously, next century, which doesn't provide a whole lot of space in 2011, those savings really come in '12, '13.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question is for Dave. Dave, when you talked about international markets, I've always had the expectation that one of the things you can really do to enhance your growth there was to gain some distribution through some acquisition. Can you comment at
componenttext: Last question is for Dave. Dave, when you talked about international markets, I've always had the expectation that one of the things you can really do to enhance your growth there was to gain some distribution through some acquisition. Can you comment at all on the visibility you have on the pipeline of deals that are out there? Some of the companies, like TreeHouse and so forth, they really have some color. They don't comment on timing or where it is because I know that's something you want to keep posted the best. But can you give us any general parameters? Is it reasonable for us to expect that you will be out there in the acquisition market, China add-on to those international franchises that you currently have?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right, I won't give you any additional parameters. I think we've been pretty clear that Latin America and Asian markets are where we're focused. Obviously, we have good cash flows. That's one of the ways we would look to redeploy those cash flows.
componenttext: You're right, I won't give you any additional parameters. I think we've been pretty clear that Latin America and Asian markets are where we're focused. Obviously, we have good cash flows. That's one of the ways we would look to redeploy those cash flows. And we're going to do a disciplined look at what's out there. And beyond that, I won't comment. We continue to be very encouraged by the organic growth of our international business and those end markets around the world. And if you can find something that both want to make sense, we certainly are interested. But I wouldn't give you anything in terms of timing or any of those other things because those things are always so opportunistic.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer, UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer, UBS.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering how you're thinking about the impact to price per volume from innovation? Obviously, we have Drops and Mini's coming. Are you going to be pushing on certain channels, packaging, price point? In addition, I'm guessing there's going to be some
componenttext: I'm wondering how you're thinking about the impact to price per volume from innovation? Obviously, we have Drops and Mini's coming. Are you going to be pushing on certain channels, packaging, price point? In addition, I'm guessing there's going to be some promotion spending upfront that might ease through to 2011. So any color that you can offer about how this might impact your mix in the coming quarters would be great.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about what we did when we look to do the pieces launch. We have done a very good job. Our sales force executes very well in terms of getting those items to market. We have the pieces and some of the newer items, but really pieces
componenttext:
Yes, I think if you think about what we did when we look to do the pieces launch. We have done a very good job. Our sales force executes very well in terms of getting those items to market. We have the pieces and some of the newer items, but really pieces in the first quarter of this year really added almost two points of growth for us into the top line. And that's been more like a point of growth from there on. And when you get to something like Mini's and Drops, they'll build meaningfully volume as you build pipeline here in December and in the first quarter. And then, that'll continue forward. 
In terms of mix, the Reese's Minis and the Hershey's Drops will be in both take-home, stand-up bags, as well as in king-sized formats on the front end. So I think from a mix standpoint, probably looks similar to the what the rest of the portfolio would look like, although we are very excited about the ability to get some amount activity on our biggest brands, Hershey and Reese's which we haven't had. So we hope that it will become a very good and consumable item in the convenience and front ends of the stores. I think, as I've said in the third quarter, innovation was additive for some other folks in the category. Bigger brands and this innovation are coming the fourth quarter and in the early part of next year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Separately, your net debt, it's dropping to less than one turn of EBITDA. The old Hershey, I think, particularly after a nice move in the stock would show up with a big repurchase of a slug of fresh air. That seems like 1 million years ago. But my God, th
componenttext: Separately, your net debt, it's dropping to less than one turn of EBITDA. The old Hershey, I think, particularly after a nice move in the stock would show up with a big repurchase of a slug of fresh air. That seems like 1 million years ago. But my God, this point, strategic investments, acquisitions are at the top of the menu. Any comments now that we're getting to these levels on net debt about how you're thinking about investments going forward?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't give any more color than we've already given. I think Dave's is right, M&A is certainly high in our list. And it is opportunistic. We're fortunate to be in a balanced situation, where we have those alternatives. And we're looking at all and con
componenttext: I wouldn't give any more color than we've already given. I think Dave's is right, M&A is certainly high in our list. And it is opportunistic. We're fortunate to be in a balanced situation, where we have those alternatives. And we're looking at all and considering them going forward. So certainly, we want to put our balance sheet to work and, I really would wouldn't comment more than that.

componenttext: I think it probably rather not comment specifically on anything other than -- as we've got into the September, October timeframe in most places, and we get into back-to-school, Halloween. We've done a very nice job of executing in getting into that season with good merchandising program. And I think it's across the board with the exception of -- I think in the food class of trade where we didn't get that kind of merchandising in this quarter. But we got it everywhere else. So I think it's really a factor of back-to-school, Halloween and some season traffic, and I'll leave it at that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And then just a follow up on, Bert, your comment on gross margin for 2011. I was a little bit unclear when you said something to this act that wouldn't be quite as strong as 2010. Were you commenting that gross margin will be directionally down, or that we just wouldn't see the massive gross margin improvement that we saw in 2010?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. We really haven't commented on direction for gross margins. But certainly, what I was trying to imply that you wouldn't expect the type of increases and gains that we've had this year. We'll provide more color as we get a little bit furth
componenttext: It's the latter. We really haven't commented on direction for gross margins. But certainly, what I was trying to imply that you wouldn't expect the type of increases and gains that we've had this year. We'll provide more color as we get a little bit further down in the year in terms of how we see that gross margin.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on spacing for next year. Just want to make sure I got a few other things are the Easter, I guess, would be later. So if you could comment on how that will impact just having the Easter season to be molder, is that maybe a positive lift fo
componenttext: Just a question on spacing for next year. Just want to make sure I got a few other things are the Easter, I guess, would be later. So if you could comment on how that will impact just having the Easter season to be molder, is that maybe a positive lift for sales at the second quarter? And then also, in terms of just as raw material increases go through next year, is there anything that we should think about in terms of timing? Is it any more or less of an impact at a certain time of the year? And then also, in terms of the way that you're expecting to manage the flow of cost savings, again, is there anything there that's sort of we should think about on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The comment on Easter, most of the Easter products are the majority for all intents and purposes shift in the first quarter. It is a longer Easter season and therefore, you would expect just to probably have more Easter shipments than we would. But then a
componenttext:
The comment on Easter, most of the Easter products are the majority for all intents and purposes shift in the first quarter. It is a longer Easter season and therefore, you would expect just to probably have more Easter shipments than we would. But then as we've talked about Valentine's and Easter moving out of the fourth quarter into the first quarter, one of the reasons is because each is a little bit later. I think what you would expect though is to see it's really anomaly in aberration and takeaway. Because as Easter gets later into April, we get the first quarter data and first quarter market share. The category might look a little slower than normal. Because the stuff fills later in each of the large component and what happens in the March, April timeframe. So I think market share and takeaway might be more affected by the later Easter. But I think shipments will still fall within the first quarter. 
With respect to productivity, if you remember, we got the last slug of Global Supply Chain Transformation productivity in the first quarter of this year. And then we don't see the Next Century productivity for the fourth quarter of 2011. So those are the two big buckets. Other than that, we are on a standard cost system. So essentially, the cost increases that Bert talked about will get spread largely across the year, based on as volumes flows out. So you kind of come up with an average projected price for yourself on a standard basis that it just flows throughout the year. So for the most part, most of that commodity gets absorbed. But commodity increases, as Bert talked about, will just get absorbed across the year with a couple of caveats around the supply chain stuff.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Beth, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to The Hershey Company Third Quarter 2010 Results. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Mark Pogharian, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Beth, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to The Hershey Company Third Quarter 2010 Results. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Mark Pogharian, you may begin your conference.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's third quarter 2010 conference call. Dave West, President and CEO; Bert Alfonso, Senior Vice President and CFO; and I will represent Hershey on this morning's call. We al
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's third quarter 2010 conference call. Dave West, President and CEO; Bert Alfonso, Senior Vice President and CFO; and I will represent Hershey on this morning's call. We also welcome those of you listening via the webcast.
Let me remind everyone listening that today's conference call may contain statements, which are forward looking. These statements are based on current expectations, which are subject to risk and uncertainty. Actual results may vary materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements because of factors such as those listed in this morning's press release and in our 10-K for 2009 filed with the SEC.
If you have not seen the press release, a copy is posted on our corporate website www.hersheys.com in the Investor Relations section. Included in the press release is a consolidated balance sheet and a summary of consolidated statements of income prepared in accordance with GAAP. Within the notes section of the press release, we have provided adjusted pro forma reconciliations of select income statement line items quantitatively reconciled to GAAP.
As we've said within the note, the company uses these non-GAAP measures as key metrics for evaluating performance internally. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to replace the presentation of financial results in accordance with GAAP, rather the company believes the presentation of earnings, excluding certain items, provides additional information to investors to facilitate the comparison of past and present operations.
We will discuss our third quarter 2010 results, excluding net pretax charges. The 2010 charges relate to the Project Next Century program, while the 2009 charges are associated with the Global Supply Chain Transformation. These pretax charges were $4.5 million in the third quarter of 2010 and $11 million in the third quarter of 2009. Our discussion of any future projections will also exclude the impact of these net charges.
With that out of the way, let me turn the call over to Dave West.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased that despite the macro economic challenges that persist, Hershey delivered another strong quarter of operating the marketplace results. During the third quarter and on a year-to-date basis, the CMG,
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased that despite the macro economic challenges that persist, Hershey delivered another strong quarter of operating the marketplace results. 
During the third quarter and on a year-to-date basis, the CMG, that's candy, mint and gum category, continues to grow, outpacing salty snacks, cookies, crackers and bakery snacks. Our business is solid in all parts of the trade, and our retail partners value the importance of the confectionery category and the leadership that Hershey provides.
During these challenging times, retailers are looking for traffic and profitable solutions, and confectionery is one of the answers to both of these objectives.
Hershey's third quarter net sales reflected continued momentum of our brands. Net sales increased 4.2%, driven primarily by volume gains in both the U.S. and international markets as we continue to invest and execute in the marketplace.
Additionally, as we exited the third quarter, the timing of some seasonal shipments dampened third quarter net sales by approximately one point. These shipments have already occurred in early October and will be reflected in our fourth quarter results.
In terms of Hershey's marketplace performance, preliminary CMG consumer takeaway for the 12 weeks ending October 2 and the year-to-date periods for our custom database in channels that account for over 80% of our income business was up about 4% and 5%, respectively.
As a reminder, these challenges include food, drug, mass, including Wal-Mart and convenience stores. In the third quarter, I was particularly pleased with the sequential improvement in retail takeaway trend at one of our larger retail customers and in the drugstore channel.
We do want to note that during the third quarter, Nielsen contacted of some of their customers, including Hershey, and informed them that they are currently reviewing the projection methodology of their C Store universe for syndicated data. This is a C Store channel specific issue, impacting a number of categories and manufacturers with the impact limited to Q3 data.
We believe the data we have been provided and that we are sharing with you today is directionally correct, and that any potential adjustment will not materially impact our overall reported market share.
We continue to feel very good about our Convenience Store business. In Atlanta at the NACS conference, that's the National Association of Convenience Stores, two weeks ago, we had the opportunity to meet with our C Store customers. The constant theme was that Hershey and the confectionery category remains solid. 
Within FDMxC, that's food, drug, mass and convenience, here we're excluding Wal-Mart, preliminary Hershey and category growth for the 12 weeks ending October 2 and year-to-date period for our custom database increased relatively in line with the category's historical growth rate. Hershey's preliminary U.S. CMG market share is up 0.2 points for the year-to-date period and was flat in the third quarter. 
The category continues to perform well despite the macro economic challenges as confectionery is among the highest with respect to household penetration and impulse purchases. This impulsivity continues to translate to merchandising opportunities. And as we move to the balance of the year, the category is a seasonal destination, with our branded products remaining available at reasonable price points. As a result, we would expect the category to continue to consistently secure key merchandising and programming space and to grow within the historical 3% to 4% range. 
The category continues to be driven by mainstream everyday confections, as trade up, gifting and novelty sub segments remain soft.
Year-to-date, premium and trade up chocolate on a net basis is about flat. As we stated in July, as expected, there were investments by major manufacturers in this category in the form of innovation and trial inducing programs during the quarter. Activity varies by channel, and despite this, Hershey retail takeaway increased in all channels.
In the third quarter, food process trade category growth was plus 4.2%. Hershey retail takeaway increased 2.5% in the third quarter, resulting in a market share decline of 0.5 points in Q3 in the food class trade. However, Hershey's food channel market share is still up 0.1 points year-to-date. Q3 results were due to the year-over-year timing of innovation, merchandising and program. Marketplace activity can and will vary from quarter-to-quarter, and our programming for the balance of the year in the food class trade is solid.
This year's Halloween season is marked by a bit of an unusual calendar. Labor Day was late, September 6 and October 31 falls on a Sunday. With this pattern, we expect consumer purchases to be especially compressed towards the end of the season. To date, customer Halloween orders and retail sell-through are tracking in line with our expectations, although we will not have a complete read on sell-through for another couple of weeks.
Halloween-specific seasonal promotions, merchandising and advertising are being executed. We believe we made the necessary investments to ensure solid category sell-through, and we work closely with key customers over the next 10 days to monitor consumer reaction and shopping behavior.
Turning now to the C Store class trade. In Q3, Hershey's preliminary C Store takeaway increased for the 10th consecutive quarter and was up within historical category growth rate, resulting in a share gain of approximately 0.2 points. On a year-to-date basis in the C Store channel, syndicated data indicates we have gained 0.6 market share points. 
In Q3, Hershey's C Store chocolate and non-chocolate performance was solid, driven by volume and mix as both standard loose bars and King Size pack types performed well in the marketplace behind the Reese's DOUBLE THE LOVE promotion and the 2 for $2.50 King Size promotion and the Hershey's Pure Happiness standard bar program.
In the fourth quarter, we expect convenience stores to remain on track behind NCAA football tie-ins, as well as additional King Size and standard bar programming. 
In the third quarter, our business in the drug class trade improved. For the 12 weeks ended October 2, Hershey's retail takeaway in this channel increased 3.2%, resulting in a market share gain of 0.6 points. While this is partly a result of easier comps versus a year-ago period, we have notably increased our level of investment and focus on this channel and are markedly improving our results.
As we look to the remainder of the year, we have strong initiatives in place during the fourth quarter across all channels. Some of the core brand merchandising and consumer promotions include NCAA football promotion, and for the holiday season, we're offering consumers a free customized photo calendar and coffee mug in conjunction with snapfish with the purchase of two participating Hershey's candy products.
We're also adding excitement for our traditional holiday and baking programming, with the Bake Share and Win promotion. And we are most excited about the December launch of Hershey's Drops and Reese's Mini's.
In Q4, versus our previous expectation, we'll accelerate the timing of and begin execution of certain aspects of our strategic plan. Therefore, SG&A spending will rise sharply and be driven by higher levels of incremental investments in the building out of the Insights Driven Performance initiative, further going market strategies in both the U.S. and other markets around the world as we add selling capability and points of distribution in global markets, such as Mexico and China.
We'll increase sampling supporting new products, especially in the markets where we are adding points of distribution. Advertising expense will increase and for the full year is now expected to be up 50% to 60%. This is greater than our previous estimate of a 45% to 50% increase. We'll increase spending on brands on which we initiated activity earlier this year. Reese's, Mounds, Almond Joy and York have responded to ad spending and will accelerate towards continuity levels of GRPs on these brands. We will also begin airing copy on Hershey's Syrup and PayDay for the first time since 2001. And we'll be adding to our consumer spending in Mexico, China and Canada as we complete and implement our demand landscape learning in these geographies.
Over the remainder of the year, we expect the macro economic challenges facing this consumer to continue. Category growth rates will most likely to continue to fluctuate from to quad-to-quad. Importantly, the inherent characteristics of the category I spoke about earlier should endure, resulting in the category grown within its historical growth rate of 3% to 4% in                             2010 and 2011. 
Our plans are in place for the upcoming key seasonal periods. As a result, we reiterate our full year  2010 net sales target outlook of about 7% increase including approximately one point benefit from foreign currency exchange rates.
For the full year, we have good visibility in our cost structure, and while input cost will be higher in the fourth quarter, we expect adjusted gross margin and adjusted EBIT margin to expand. Therefore, we have increased our full year adjusted earnings per share-diluted outlook and expected to be in the $2.52 to $2.56 range, an increase of mid- to high-teens on a percentage basis versus 2009,   and greater than our previously estimated range of $2.47 to $2.52.   
As we plan for 2011, we believe macro economic challenges and consumer confidence will continue to be a headwind. However, we believe category dynamics, similar to those I've discussed, and continued support of our brands will enable the category and Hershey to grow.
In 2011, we expect our advertising expense to increase. However, the year-over-year percentage increase will not be at the rates achieved over the last two years. As a result, our initial expectation for 2011 is for net sales growth within our 3% to 5% long-term objective. While we do anticipate higher input cost in 2011, productivity and cost-saving initiatives are in place to help mitigate the impact. Therefore, based on our current views and expectations for 2011, we expect growth and adjusted earnings per share diluted within our current long-term target of 6% to 8%.
I'll now turn it over to Bert who will provide some additional financial details.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Hershey posted another quarter of quality results, as third quarter consolidated net sales of $1,547,000,000 increased 4.2% versus the prior year and adjusted earnings per share diluted of $0.79 increased 8.2%.O
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Hershey posted another quarter of quality results, as third quarter consolidated net sales of $1,547,000,000 increased 4.2% versus the prior year and adjusted earnings per share diluted of $0.79 increased 8.2%.
Overall, year-over-year result were driven by volume, mix, net price realization and supply chain savings which more than offset increases in marketing investments and selling capabilities. The third quarter sales gain of 4.2% was driven primarily by the continued growth of our core brands including new products. As we ended the quarter, the timing of some seasonal shipments lowered our third quarter net sales by about one point. Therefore, our fourth quarter seasonal shipments will be greater than the prior year, maintaining our full year net sales outlook of about 7%. In addition, lower levels of customer returns in markdowns, as well as the July 2009 carryover pricing in Canada, generated net price realization of about one point, while favorable foreign currency rates contributed approximately a half point.
During the third quarter, adjusted gross margin increased 290 basis points, driven by favorable supply chain efficiencies, including continued higher productivity, favorable sales mix and lower levels of obsolescence. Input costs were about flat in the quarter and favorable versus our previous estimate as a result of certain commodity strategies executed in Q3. We currently have good visibility for our cost structure for the remainder of the year and expect input cost to be higher in the fourth quarter versus prior year. Despite this increase, year-over-year adjusted gross margin is expected to be a bit higher in the fourth quarter but below the rate achieved in the third quarter.
Third quarter adjusted EBIT margins of 19.7% is up 10 basis points. This is driven primarily by higher adjusted gross margin, offset by higher advertising expense, up about  46%; selling expenses, as we continue to invest in consumer insight in building global capabilities and employee-related expenses. As Dave stated earlier, we continue to invest in our core brands and expect full year advertising expense to increase 50% to 60%, greater than our previous estimate of 45% to 50%. 
So as the last year, as previously communicated, we are planning additional advertising in the fourth quarter in both the U.S. and other key markets to enable a strong start to 2011. We expect adjusted EBIT margin to expand for the full year, although it will be lower versus the fourth quarter of last year.
And that's due to lower gross margin expansion as well as business investments, which Dave already described.
Now let me provide an update on our international businesses. Overall, our reported sales outside the U.S. increased low double digits. And on a reported and constant-currency basis, sales increased in our largest international markets. While in Asia, we focused on preparing for the upcoming Chinese New Year. During the third quarter, strategic investments in brand building and go-to-market strategies were higher, including an advertising increase of 65% outside of North America.
As a result of our local currency basis, operating income increased in Canada but declined in the rest of our emerging market businesses. We are committed to investing in our international businesses. And we anticipate that these investments will generate meaningful brand awareness and some raw faith over time.
Moving further down to P&L. For the quarter, interest expense was $22.3 million, consistent with the prior period. In 2010, we now expect interest expense to be down about 1% versus 2009. The tax rate for the third quarter was 35.1% or 210 basis points less than the prior year due to the impact of interim tax accounting and a favorable income mix among geographies. For the full year, we now expect the tax rate to be about 35% to 35.5%, slightly higher than our previous estimate of 35%.
In the third quarter of 2010, weighted average shares outstanding on a diluted basis were $230.5 million versus $229.6 million in 2009, leading to adjusted earnings per share diluted of $0.79, up 8.2% versus a year ago.
Let me provide a quick recap of our year-to-date results. Net sales increased 7.6%. Adjusted gross margin was 43% year-to-date versus 38.3% last year. Gains were driven primarily by favorable supply chain efficiencies including volume and greater levels of productivity. Favorable mix and low obsolescence also contributed. Adjusted EBIT increased 23.5%, thus resulting an EBIT margin gain of 230 basis points to 18.3% from 16%. Advertising increased 54% on a year-to-date basis. And adjusted earnings per share diluted for the nine-month period increased 26% to $1.94 per share.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. At the end of the third quarter, net trading capital is relatively in line with last year. Accounts receivable was up $38 million and remains extremely current and of high quality. We continuously monitor our accounts receivable aging, and despite current macro economic conditions, we have not seen an impact on our customers' payment patterns to date. 
Inventory increased $35 million, driven partially by previously mentioned timing of the third quarter sales, while accounts payable increased by $65 million. We do expect net trading capital to improve in the fourth quarter, as we cycle through the peak seasonal period of our business. 
In terms of other specific cash flow items, capital additions,  including software, were $49 million in the third quarter and $124 million year-to-date. The amounts included $20 million of Project Next Century capital expenditures. For 2010, we're targeting total capital additions to be in the $190 million to $210 million range. This range includes base ongoing CapEx of $140 million to $160 million plus Project Next Century CapEx of approximately $50 million. 
Depreciation and amortization was $52 million in the period, including a solid depreciation of approximately $6 million. Year-to-date, reported depreciation amortization was $146 million and included $7 million of accelerated depreciation related to the Next Century program. 
Therefore, adjusted operating depreciation and amortization year-to-date was approximately $139 million. In 2010, we are forecasting total operating depreciation and amortization of  $175 million to $185 million, while accelerated depreciation amortization related to Project Next Century is expected to be $10 million to $15 million.
Dividend space during the quarter were $71 million. We did not acquire stock in the third quarter related to the outstanding repurchase program. There remains 100 million outstanding on the current authorization. Year-to-date, approximately 133 million of our common shares have been repurchased to replace shares issued in conjunction with stock option exercises and option replenishment is about current at quarter end.
Cash on hand at the end of the third quarter was $245 million, up versus the year ago period and relatively in line with 2009 year-end balance. As we exit the third quarter, we are well positioned to manage the capital needs of the business as well as higher capital expenditure requirements of Project Next Century. 
Now let me provide an update on Project Next Century. I'm pleased to confirm that we have begun work on West Hershey plant expansion. Excavation on the property has begun, and we expect to begin receiving manufacturing equipment during the third quarter of 2011. We also anticipate initial production line startup during the fourth quarter of 2011 with continued rollout and implementation throughout 2012.
The forecast for total pretax GAAP charges and nonrecurring project implementation costs remains at $140 million to $170 million. For 2010, total GAAP charges related to the program are expected to be $75 million to $85 million. 
By 2014, when we continue to expect annual savings of approximately $60 million and $80 million. In terms of the timing, savings for Project Next Century will not be realized until late 2011 with the majority coming in 2012 and 2013. During the quarter, we recorded net pretax charges of $4.5 million for Project Next Century, consisting mostly of accelerated depreciation. 
Now let me summarize. We are pleased with our third quarter and year-to-date results. Our goal for the remainder of the year is to successfully launch new products, including Hershey's Drops and Reese's Mini's and to maintain our marketplace momentum as we exit 2010 and enter 2011.
To support this objective, we plan to increase full year advertising expense by 50% to 60%. In addition, we expect to see some shift in 2011 seasonal orders from the fourth quarter 2010 into the first quarter of 2011 due to the timing and refinement of shipments. As a result, we reaffirm our full year 2010 net sales outlook of about 7% versus 2009, including an approximate one point benefit from current foreign currency exchange rates.
We have good visibility for our cost structure for the remainder of 2010 and expect input costs to be higher in the fourth quarter. Despite this increase, adjusted gross margin expected to be a bit higher in the fourth quarter, but not at the rate achieved in Q3, a potentially subject to the volatility of the dairy markets. Additionally, we do not expect LIFO inventory to be favorable as it was in Q4 2009. 
Given our strong business results, we will make additional fourth quarter strategic investments in both the U.S. and international markets that we do not initially plan. These investments will benefit Hershey both in the short and long term.
Aside from the aforementioned increase in advertising plans, these include acceleration and increase of Insights Driven Performance, additional selling and go-to-market strategies in both the U.S. and international markets and higher sampling to support new products and distribution. Given our continued momentum, we have increased our full year adjusted earnings per share-diluted outlook and expect to be in the $2.52 to $2.56 range, an increase of mid- to high-teens on a percentage basis versus 2009 and greater than our previously estimated range of $2.47 to $2.52. 
As we look to 2011, we'll continue to focus on our core brands and leverage Hershey's scale at retail. Advertising expense is expected to increase in 2011. However, the year-over-year percentage will be lower than the previous two years.
Our current expectation for 2011 is for net sales growth to be within 3% to 5% long-term target. While we anticipate higher input cost in 2011, productivity and cost saving initiatives are in place to help mitigate the impact. Included in our productivity outlook is a portion of the additional $80 million to $100 million we identified at CAGNY. While we achieved more of these savings in the second half of 2010 that we initially estimated primarily in cost of sales, the majority of these savings will still be attained in 2011 and 2012. Although starting next year, some of these savings will also flow through the SM&A line.
Therefore, while still early, given our current views regarding business investments and cost structure, we expect 2011 growth in adjusted earnings per share diluted to be within our long-term target of 6% to 8%.
Let's now open it up for Q&A.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jonathan Feeney, Janney Montgomery.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jonathan Feeney, Janney Montgomery.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Only one question I had is, when you look at the guidance for next year, clearly, it's been a period here of some pretty significant competitive share gain, it appears. What are you hearing -- are we seeing in that 6% to 8% guidance a thought that maybe s
componenttext: Only one question I had is, when you look at the guidance for next year, clearly, it's been a period here of some pretty significant competitive share gain, it appears. What are you hearing -- are we seeing in that 6% to 8% guidance a thought that maybe some competitive activity would accelerate from Wrigley Masterfoods who seem to have been out of the market in a lot of places? What kind of competitive assumptions go into that guidance as you look forward to 2011? And to the extent you can-- comment on anything different at the margin.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Jon, what I would say is the view of the category that we talked about, the category growth rate continues to be within the longer term. This is a 3% of 4% growth category. Actually, on a year-to-date basis, this is growing a little bit better th
componenttext: I think, Jon, what I would say is the view of the category that we talked about, the category growth rate continues to be within the longer term. This is a 3% of 4% growth category. Actually, on a year-to-date basis, this is growing a little bit better than that 4%. So we would start with the category growth assumption. And then, within that category growth assumption, say, we don't see anything changes that longer-term growth algorithm for 2011. And we would expect to be competitive with respect to programming and share. So in the third quarter here, we were flattish on share. We're still up on a share this year on a year-to-date basis. And we would expect the gives and the takes in the marketplace are such that you start with that 3% to 4% assumption and assume we're going to be competitive within the share gain. And that's kind of how we start the algorithm. There was a lot of activity in the third quarter, which we had talked to you about in July. That was around innovation for some of the competitors in gum and in chocolate. And that happened in the third quarter. And despite that competitive activity and innovation, we still were able to basically hold on to our share in the third quarter.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens, JPMorgan.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
