componenttextpreview: In Q4, do you expect kind of the inflow you've identified from the third quarter to roughly equate to the outflow you've talked about for Q1?
componenttext: In Q4, do you expect kind of the inflow you've identified from the third quarter to roughly equate to the outflow you've talked about for Q1?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the way to think about that, Terry. I think when we talk to you at the end of the second quarter of the call, we were still looking at some Valentines and Easter shifting out of the fourth quarter into the first quarter of next year. T
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the way to think about that, Terry. I think when we talk to you at the end of the second quarter of the call, we were still looking at some Valentines and Easter shifting out of the fourth quarter into the first quarter of next year. That shift still happens. But it's now offset in the fourth quarter by a little bit of Halloween that moved out of September and October. So I think what you're seeing is that those two things now offset each other in the fourth quarter number.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dave, we have a source that's occasionally right on C Stores, not always. So we were looking at roughly around 6% growth in the C Store channel during Q3. Is that close to what you guys saw?
componenttext: And Dave, we have a source that's occasionally right on C Stores, not always. So we were looking at roughly around 6% growth in the C Store channel during Q3. Is that close to what you guys saw?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our growth was not quite that, Terry. We gained some share in the quarter. I think on a year-to-date basis, we're still feeling the C Store is outperforming most of the other classes of trade, but we didn't see that kind of 6% number.
componenttext: Our growth was not quite that, Terry. We gained some share in the quarter. I think on a year-to-date basis, we're still feeling the C Store is outperforming most of the other classes of trade, but we didn't see that kind of 6% number.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just more generally, and I guess this question always comes up. The cash flow, of course, looks very good here. I guess, you guys do have a bond that expires this year and maybe a note next year. But could you just give us your general thoughts o
componenttext: And then just more generally, and I guess this question always comes up. The cash flow, of course, looks very good here. I guess, you guys do have a bond that expires this year and maybe a note next year. But could you just give us your general thoughts on allotment of cash flow here?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're obviously pleased with our cash flow. And we have cash on the balance sheet now, which wouldn’t have been true last year where we were still in the commercial paper market. In terms of our bond maturity, we do have a bond maturing next year,
componenttext: Yes, we're obviously pleased with our cash flow. And we have cash on the balance sheet now, which wouldn’t have been true last year where we were still in the commercial paper market. In terms of our bond maturity, we do have a bond maturing next year, and that's in 2011. And so obviously, we're already thinking about that, given that it's already moved from long-term to short-term position on the balance sheet. Cash flow continues to be good. And I already mentioned, we're about current on our share repurchase program, with respect to replenishment of stock options. The question that always comes up, obviously, is around buyback and that may be what you're insinuating it's the discussion that we seriously had with the board, and we continue to have that. And we have other options in terms of  cash use. So we're pleased with where we are from a cash flow perspective, working capital and otherwise, strong gross margin growth. And we'll take the appropriate action going forward.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question, Alexia Howard, Morgan Stanley. [Bernstein]
componenttext: Your next question, Alexia Howard, Morgan Stanley. [Bernstein]

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alexia Howard, from Bernstein here. I'd like to hear little bit more in China and India. I know that you talked a little bit about it earlier on. Are you able to actually comment on what percentage of sales those two markets are expected to contribute in
componenttext: Alexia Howard, from Bernstein here. I'd like to hear little bit more in China and India. I know that you talked a little bit about it earlier on. Are you able to actually comment on what percentage of sales those two markets are expected to contribute in 2010? And what kind of lift are you getting on the quarterly numbers, in terms of how much it's contributing to sales growth year-on-year? And maybe just more broadly or qualitatively, what lessons have you learned and what do you see as the biggest opportunities in those two markets?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we have made some investments outside of the U.S. pretty broadly. Asia is a place where we are investing. We've invested in some go-to-market capabilities with respect to the way we're distributing and selling in both India and China. I think
componenttext:
Yes, I think we have made some investments outside of the U.S. pretty broadly. Asia is a place where we are investing. We've invested in some go-to-market capabilities with respect to the way we're distributing and selling in both India and China. I think that the international growth rates added, maybe, let's call it 100 basis points of the growth in the quarter to our growth rates. Again, that's across the board. The third quarter in China particularly is a seasonally light quarter because we ramp up for the Chinese New Year, which is in the early part of next year. And that ramp up really starts in September on. So there's not a lot of activity sales-wise in China. 
In the third quarter, we spent some time building out distribution. We will support our brand in China in the fourth quarter, when I talk about the incremental advertising spending that we're having in the fourth quarter. China is one of the places where we are certainly adding some sampling and some support behind our brand. And as I think about our plans for 2011 on a go-forward basis, we would expect that the non-U.S. businesses would be added to the top line growth rate for next year as well.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question, Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question, Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just sort of your initial outlook for 2011, you're going to have a very tough comps against 2010 on the top line. So what it is in particular that's giving you the confidence that you can still sustain what will be pretty robust top line growth next year?
componenttext: Just sort of your initial outlook for 2011, you're going to have a very tough comps against 2010 on the top line. So what it is in particular that's giving you the confidence that you can still sustain what will be pretty robust top line growth next year? Is it the advertising level, the promotion or the work you're doing around some of the Mounds and Almond Joy-type brands? What is it that's driving that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A combination of things, in the U.S. in particular. Our innovation, we launched Pieces earlier this year and that's done very well. But remember, we have the Hershey's Drops and the Reese's Mini's that will ship in December, and so that innovation that be
componenttext: A combination of things, in the U.S. in particular. Our innovation, we launched Pieces earlier this year and that's done very well. But remember, we have the Hershey's Drops and the Reese's Mini's that will ship in December, and so that innovation that becomes additive for us next year. We have other innovation in our pipeline for 2011 that we feel very good about. And so that will be an additive component for us next year. We are advertising and added some GRPs across the number of brands this year. We are in the fourth quarter, increasing the GRP levels on Mounds and Almond Joy and York. And then, we’re adding some advertising support across PayDay and Hershey's Syrup for the first time since 2001. So that will add to -- we think that the impression of the brand, and then we're also continuing to look at better sales force execution. And we're gaining some distribution points in the convenience class of trade, as we brought on extra resources this year. So we have a number of additive leverage that we've invested in this year. And we'll start to test Insights Driven Performance, which we are investing in here pretty significantly in the back half of the year. It will be more on a pilot form next year. We think it will help us as we get set up for the last part of '11 and into 2012.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the investments in the International business. Is there any chance you can give us just a little bit on how dilutive you think investment in international is going to be for the next couple of years? And then also, your market share gai
componenttext: Can you talk about the investments in the International business. Is there any chance you can give us just a little bit on how dilutive you think investment in international is going to be for the next couple of years? And then also, your market share gains are great this year. But they are slowing. And yet, you're dialing up advertising, and you have a huge increase this year in advertising. Why wouldn't these gains be more sustainable? Or do you just think the competition is having a go-at-it in the third quarter, and now you're going to launch your new products and that will kind of reverse it the other way again, as we head into the next couple of quarters.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good questions, Rob. I'll probably just give you some perspective. On a year-to-date basis, FDMxC W, so that's kind of 80% of the universe. So I'm talking year-to-date. Our takeaway is up 4.7%. So that's barely solid nine months through '10 to take away.
componenttext:
Good questions, Rob. I'll probably just give you some perspective. On a year-to-date basis, FDMxC W, so that's kind of 80% of the universe. So I'm talking year-to-date. Our takeaway is up 4.7%. So that's barely solid nine months through '10 to take away. And if you look at the third quarter takeaway, we were up roughly 3.5%. So our FDMxC W takeaway was 3.5%, and we held share within that 3.5%. So we still are seeing 3.5%, pick a number, 3.5%, 4.5% category in terms of takeaway growth. So good numbers. Within the third quarter, we were sequentially much better in the drug class trade for the first time in the number of quarters. We actually gained share in drug. And we talked about 3.2% takeaway and a 60 basis point gain in share in drug. And we were very pleased with the sequential improvement in the mass retailers. And in convenience, we held and gained a little bit of share, as well in the quarter. Where we lost share, the one area, which I talked about, was we lost the last half of a share point in food, off of the 2.5% takeaway growth. And that's really where we lost some merchandising in the third quarter. We had talked about some new items that some of the other chocolate competitors were coming with in the third quarter. We lost some merchandising in food. And we also moved away from a promoted price point on one of our pack types that we didn't like particularly much in food that wasn't as profitable for us. 
So when I we think about the business overall in the third quarter, still good category growth rates, although a little bit more of share skirmish. And remember, our innovation comes in the fourth quarter in the form of Reese's Mini's and Hershey's Drops. So overall, the category is still growing very well. We feel very good about it. We've got volume returns in this category, and I think the growth rates are pretty good. So the advertising it's working on the brands, we're putting in. And then we significantly added some advertising spending. We've been fortunate to be performing pretty well in the last few years within the U.S. business. And as that U.S. business has performed well, we've taken advantage of the opportunity to go up and take the demand landscape learning that worked so well for us in the U.S. And we used that learning in Canada, Mexico, China for example, and what we're now doing is accelerating our investments in go-to-market capabilities, as well as in brand building in those markets. So we've absorbed that type of ramp-up in spending in the international markets in our results for the last two years. And when we talk about next year, we also see similar kinds of investments in international within the long term, 6% to 8% number that we gave you. So we're able to continue to grow our earnings base and still do those international investments.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You don't want to give us a number on the dilution effect?
componenttext: You don't want to give us a number on the dilution effect?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, I think in Bert's remarks we said it, that operating income -- the only market outside the U.S. where we saw operating income growth was in Canada. We had operating income declines in the rest of the market. So it clearly has the dilutiv
componenttext: Just to be clear, I think in Bert's remarks we said it, that operating income -- the only market outside the U.S. where we saw operating income growth was in Canada. We had operating income declines in the rest of the market. So it clearly has the dilutive effect for us. But we are, as I said, we've been able to absorb that in our core businesses in the U.S., and in particularly, in Canada with the investment levels. And we see ourselves able to do that again in the next year and into the long term as we talk about that 6% to 8%.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow, BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Zaslow, BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the timing between advertising spending and the incremental sales growth? What I'm trying to get a sense of is, when Hershey's spend $1 of advertising, how do you assess or how do you expect to get the incremental sales growth? And just
componenttext: Can you talk about the timing between advertising spending and the incremental sales growth? What I'm trying to get a sense of is, when Hershey's spend $1 of advertising, how do you assess or how do you expect to get the incremental sales growth? And just the timing of how that works? Because you are spending a lot of advertising and I would expect it to kind of have an implication for 2011. So if you can just bridge that a little bit, that'd be helpful.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, and I think we've mentioned this before, we take a pretty disciplined approach in terms of our ad spending. And so we keep a keen eye on how we think about ROI. Clearly, brands with scale are the ones that will give you the better ROI. So you
componenttext:
I would say, and I think we've mentioned this before, we take a pretty disciplined approach in terms of our ad spending. And so we keep a keen eye on how we think about ROI. Clearly, brands with scale are the ones that will give you the better ROI. So you're right, there's certainly is a lag effect in terms of advertising spend today and brand building in consumer's minds and purchases in the future. 
So as we think about fourth quarter spend in particular, we do expect them, and we have our own internal calculations of how that impacts the first couple of quarters of next year. And certainly, there's a positive correlation. We look at those ROIs on a brand basis, on a monthly basis as well. So it's not something that we do at long intervals. We keep a constant review of what that ad spend is. When Dave mentioned Syrup and PayDay, which we haven't had on air since 2009. Certainly, there was a lot of analytical and work done around that -- or 2001, rather, a lot of analytical work beyond that to determine whether those were right two brands to put on air and at what levels. 
So the only thing that I would add to that, which is a different dynamic, is in international markets, ROIs certainly are lower. And that gets back to the scale comment that I meant earlier, the larger the brand, the greater lift you're going to get simply based on that scale. And so in the international market, it's more about long-term brand building. But in the U.S., their payoffs are much more immediate. And they normally, as we think of it, come in the next couple of quarters.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: How many more brands? And I know you won't tell me which ones. But how many more brands do you have that have significant underinvestment similar like a PayDay or the Syrup? It sounds like, are you coming to the end of that? And then, are going to move to
componenttext: How many more brands? And I know you won't tell me which ones. But how many more brands do you have that have significant underinvestment similar like a PayDay or the Syrup? It sounds like, are you coming to the end of that? And then, are going to move to the international? Or is there still some runway in terms of the non-chocolate confectionery side?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We never say we're come to the end. That sounds like a -- let me rephrase that . We've gotten good investment on the majority of the brands that we would expect to see good lifts. We've been able to accelerate some of them. We certainly were able to do Mo
componenttext:
We never say we're come to the end. That sounds like a -- let me rephrase that . We've gotten good investment on the majority of the brands that we would expect to see good lifts. We've been able to accelerate some of them. We certainly were able to do Mounds, Almond Joy and York earlier this year based on the successes that we had back in 2009. And we're able to do PayDay and Hershey's Syrup a little bit earlier than we would've expected. So maybe another brand or so. 
And in with respect to international, in the last two years, we've already made those investments. I think Bert mentioned the number was about 65% or so increase in ad spending in the international markets outside the U.S. in the third quarter. So that's already in our numbers. And so when you see the increases in advertising as we kind of roll through the year, what we are doing is really accelerating some of the strategic plan work that we're doing, with respect to the demand landscape work that we've shared with you to get some of the brands where we think we can activate them pretty smartly because they have some unique characteristics. And then, in the international markets, I think we're applying some of the really good learnings from the U.S. and doing it a little quicker than I think we would have expected we would've gotten to it.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Judy Hong, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Judy Hong, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason English, here. The outlook and how you keep the momentum going, inflation is obviously a concern, I think you guys are calling it out in your press release. You mentioned as a potential headwind for next year. As you lay out guidance here, what degr
componenttext: Jason English, here. The outlook and how you keep the momentum going, inflation is obviously a concern, I think you guys are calling it out in your press release. You mentioned as a potential headwind for next year. As you lay out guidance here, what degree of inflation are you guys contemplating within that?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of our cost basket, and you're right, we're certainly anticipating just based on our internal estimates and the visibility that we have for next year already. We certainly expect that commodities, as an example, will be ramping up next year
componenttext: Yes, in terms of our cost basket, and you're right, we're certainly anticipating just based on our internal estimates and the visibility that we have for next year already. We certainly expect that commodities, as an example, will be ramping up next year in terms of cost. We've done awful lot of productivity programs behind providing offset there. And in terms of gross margin, we don't expect to repeat that type of performance that we had this year in a more benign commodity environment. So we're continuously looking for ways to offset that inflation within the manufacturing space. But there's no doubt that inflation is a headwind next year compared to this year. We have it built into how we think about the top line and bottom line. And we still believe we have leverage in the P&L to be able to achieve within that 6% to 8%. But the composition of next year's cost basket is more inflated than this year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it possible for you guys to quantify what you're thinking in terms of range? And you mentioned that you're also thinking about the impact on top line. Can I interpret that to mean that you're contemplating some pricing moves to help you mitigate this?
componenttext: Is it possible for you guys to quantify what you're thinking in terms of range? And you mentioned that you're also thinking about the impact on top line. Can I interpret that to mean that you're contemplating some pricing moves to help you mitigate this?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not going to comment on pricing at all. I think with prepared comments we're really around the input cost in terms of inflation. And our cost basket is frankly a bit different than some of the other folks in the food space, we're bigger buyers of co
componenttext: We're not going to comment on pricing at all. I think with prepared comments we're really around the input cost in terms of inflation. And our cost basket is frankly a bit different than some of the other folks in the food space, we're bigger buyers of cocoa and sugar and dairies, and we're not in the green complex as much as others. So I'm not sure our inflation assumptions would be translatable for you. For competitor reasons, we're not going to get into that kind of a blow-by-blow, commodity by commodity. We do expect that our basket will be higher overall. But we have very good productivity in place to offset some of that. And we think that's how we're planning our business for 2011.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think through the first half of the year, you mentioned that the trade scale was running below initial expectations. Has that changed and do you see a need to see bring more trade spend in the market?
componenttext: I think through the first half of the year, you mentioned that the trade scale was running below initial expectations. Has that changed and do you see a need to see bring more trade spend in the market?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The rate in the third quarter was about flat versus the prior year's rate. In the first half of the year, we had actually been a little bit favorable on a rate basis. And when we have gotten in the second quarter call, I think we had said that, that would
componenttext: The rate in the third quarter was about flat versus the prior year's rate. In the first half of the year, we had actually been a little bit favorable on a rate basis. And when we have gotten in the second quarter call, I think we had said that, that would likely abate as we got in the back half. And so the rate is roughly in line with what it was a year ago. And again, I think when you see retailers will choose what price points they want to run, particularly the seasonal events that. So far what we've seen year-over-year on Halloween in the marketplace is the pricing is roughly equivalent on a promoted basis, as it was year ago.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, the back half is always a little bit more, if you want to call it, intense because it has a higher seasonal component. But we're not seeing anything that's a lot different than what we anticipated.
componenttext: I mean, the back half is always a little bit more, if you want to call it, intense because it has a higher seasonal component. But we're not seeing anything that's a lot different than what we anticipated.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar, Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar, Barclays Capital.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow up a little bit for the one you just had. I guess, some food companies, when they think about their long-term sort of top and bottom line growth algorithm, they'll say our intent over time is to either offset inflation through pricing,
componenttext: Just a quick follow up a little bit for the one you just had. I guess, some food companies, when they think about their long-term sort of top and bottom line growth algorithm, they'll say our intent over time is to either offset inflation through pricing, such that we have -- productivity to fund the marketing and what not to drive the top line. Or we attempt to offset inflation through a combination of pricing and cost saves or what have you. And I don't know, I apologize but I just can't remember, have you gotten that granular around your long-term growth algorithm? And ultimately, how you anticipate handling inflation over time?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have not actually given that level of specificity. And I think one of the reasons we're a little bit more cautious about giving that much specific detail is, we're the only ones in the confection space who are giving certain public pronouncements. And
componenttext:
We have not actually given that level of specificity. And I think one of the reasons we're a little bit more cautious about giving that much specific detail is, we're the only ones in the confection space who are giving certain public pronouncements. And competitively, we'd like to keep our, particularly our commodity strategies a little bit more closer to the vest. I think in principle, Andrew, what you're saying is absolutely right. Over time, you would like to offset and pass on the appropriate increase in your cost basket. We have been particularly aggressive, I think, within our supply chain, obviously, with the Global Supply Chain Transformation project that we completed, where we closed seven  facilities and built the new one in Monterrey, Mexico. We have what we're calling Project Next Century where we're working very hard to continue to improve the efficiencies of our bakeries -- of our plant here in Hershey, rebuilding a new facility, we're going to invest a couple of hundred million dollars here in our home market. 
So we look at those productivity programs, as well as just better efficiency in the business by focusing on the core to have given us the flexibility to meet the issues within our cost basket, as well as our investment needs. But on a go-forward basis, I think in principle, I would say, we would like to be able to deal with input pressures and eventually be able to pass those along to the consumers as appropriate. But I think the other thing that's somewhat unique about the category is that it's so promotionally intensive and so much of it moves under merchandising, it's really less about list pricing and how come consumers think about promoted price points over time. And those are a little harder to move. They tend to move in bigger increments than simple list prices. So there's an algorithm for us that maybe a little bit more difficult to implement because of the significant portion of our business, which is seasonal and merchandised in that way. We have historically, as a category, tended to move in bigger increments on promoted prices than maybe you'd see in other categories. But we do, over time expect that we'd like to pass on those kinds of costs.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do recall that in the last one that you took a while back, you did move the promoted price point. And the move in that price was much more dramatic in whatever it was, 20% for 25% kind of move.
componenttext: I do recall that in the last one that you took a while back, you did move the promoted price point. And the move in that price was much more dramatic in whatever it was, 20% for 25% kind of move.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That 20% or 25% is correct.
componenttext: That 20% or 25% is correct.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just kind of keeping on that same theme, but not to beat a dead horse. The last time the industry or the category raised prices so aggressively, there was kind of I'd say more of elasticity than maybe was initially expected. And I think, Dave, yo
componenttext: I guess, just kind of keeping on that same theme, but not to beat a dead horse. The last time the industry or the category raised prices so aggressively, there was kind of I'd say more of elasticity than maybe was initially expected. And I think, Dave, you suggested that the premium end of the category is still kind of flattish or not keeping up with the mass part of the business. And so does that kind of suggest to you that putting through a price increase would be met by a fair amount of elasticity, given what you see from the consumer segments within confection?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Eric, let me just clarify my point. Premium and trade up when you look at it at an aggregate is about roughly flat for the year. Those two segments are not contributing on a combined basis. They're not really contributing to category growth. It re
componenttext:
I think Eric, let me just clarify my point. Premium and trade up when you look at it at an aggregate is about roughly flat for the year. Those two segments are not contributing on a combined basis. They're not really contributing to category growth. It really still is very much a mainstream story. I think when we did take our pricing action that we announced in August of '08 and implemented really in '09 and then it spilled over a little bit into early 2010, we did see volumes return a little more quickly than we would've expected from our modeling. So we were very encouraged by that. 
What we all have to continue to monitor is consumer behavior and where consumers are today and how they're thinking about value. One of the big beautiful things about our category is it is an approachable luxury and/or indulgence at a time when consumers are looking for that. So the category dynamics right now, as I've said, we've got good growth in the category. It's a very volume-oriented category. And people are playing the innovation approach right now in the category. We've feel very good about that. So we think the category growth rates are strong where they are. I don't want to talk very much about forward pricing. I think the one of the other factors is, as you’re taking a look at pricing, is what's happening around you in the entire rest of the basket. And I think there seems to be some inflationary pressure. Retailers are talking about it. And it looks like some other folks are also, in other categories are going need to do some things. 
So that's also a big factor -- is our prices in any category moving up by themselves or are they moving in context of the entire basket? So all of those things, I think, would impact the way the modeling would work' for us. We clearly model it out constantly. And I think what I would say right now is, we're pretty comfortable with where our businesses and that we've got volume returning. And beyond, I don't think I'll comment any further on anything that's happened in the market.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the last time I heard Hershey talk about getting more aggressive with PayDay. It was kind of towards the end of the growth story. I think you tried to position that as a sports kind of bar or something along those lines. And that didn't work. And
componenttext: I think the last time I heard Hershey talk about getting more aggressive with PayDay. It was kind of towards the end of the growth story. I think you tried to position that as a sports kind of bar or something along those lines. And that didn't work. And so, I guess I just point that out in that you do have the new Drops and bite-sized type stuff that seems to be working. I mean, is the next move kind of an enrobed product which you don't really have in your, let's say, quiver? As I've said before, I think that the Drops and stuff is kind of like a bite-sized M&M type product, and the one thing that you haven't been successful at is putting out something that competes with Snickers or Milky Way or something along those lines.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the reference you make to positioning PayDay as an energy bar. We had a product that we had that we called PayDay Pro which had higher levels and more grams of protein and it-- that's not the product we're talking about, what we are talking about
componenttext:
I think the reference you make to positioning PayDay as an energy bar. We had a product that we had that we called PayDay Pro which had higher levels and more grams of protein and it-- that's not the product we're talking about, what we are talking about here is supporting the PayDay bar itself. We haven't had advertising on air since 2001. And we think PayDay is uniquely positioned in the demand landscape work that we have in our portfolio, that it doesn't really interact with much else that we have in the portfolio. 
So we think it can be pretty incremental for us. We do think that Hershey's Drops and Reese's Mini's launches will be good launches for us. We're excited about. And we will support them with advertising unique to those items. And we have other innovation that's planned for 2011, which we're not at this point in time going to reveal to you. But again, we are very anchored in the demand landscape in terms of what's incremental to the portfolio and where white spaces in the category. And I think we'll share some more of that when we get into the early part of the year, probably at CAGNY.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You moved and created a new facility in Monterrey, and all you hear out of that city is pretty tough conditions. Is that something to be concerned about? Like is that a facility that you use for the export market or does that come back in here? Or do you
componenttext: You moved and created a new facility in Monterrey, and all you hear out of that city is pretty tough conditions. Is that something to be concerned about? Like is that a facility that you use for the export market or does that come back in here? Or do you have the capacity utilization to meet demand if things get worse there as opposed to better?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The facilities in Monterrey, Mexico, it is producing products for the U.S. market. We have embarked like many of the companies in the Fortune 500 and beyond, on a pretty robust Enterprise Risk Management or ERM program. Supply in sourcing is one of those
componenttext: The facilities in Monterrey, Mexico, it is producing products for the U.S. market. We have embarked like many of the companies in the Fortune 500 and beyond, on a pretty robust Enterprise Risk Management or ERM program. Supply in sourcing is one of those things that's in that. So this is something that we continuously look at, source of supply not just in Monterrey but throughout our network. We have experienced no issues in Monterrey with respect to our manufacturing facility. And we haven't experienced any issues bringing products across the borders, et cetera. As a matter of fact, that project went very well for us. It achieved its milestone. The productivity that we got from that back in '09 and closed up this year is very strong. So we're pleased with how that's gone. It's no different than any other supply situation. You continue to monitor your inventory levels, and it is something that's part of an ERM program we look at, but we are pleased with where we are.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll, Citi Investment.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll, Citi Investment.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On commodity inflation for 2011, Bert, can you just comment on whether or not you feel good about your visibility into the cost structure for 2011 at this juncture?
componenttext: On commodity inflation for 2011, Bert, can you just comment on whether or not you feel good about your visibility into the cost structure for 2011 at this juncture?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, what we said towards at the end of -- or at least what I tried to communicate toward the end of my prepared remarks. There certainly is much more commodity inflation. We haven't experienced as much this year as we thought. In the third quarter
componenttext:
Yes, David, what we said towards at the end of -- or at least what I tried to communicate toward the end of my prepared remarks. There certainly is much more commodity inflation. We haven't experienced as much this year as we thought. In the third quarter, and we thought we've had some higher commodities. I mentioned that. It was really kind of flat. We did that change starting the fourth quarter starts to move up, and we see that some of that continuing. 
Certainly, at this time of the year, we start to get some reasonable visibility. In terms of next year, we're very focused on being able to say more about that later on. And also, very focused against the productivity programs of which right now, we mentioned the CAGNY programs that starts to deliver even more next year, not just on cost of goods line but also below that. So at the moment, we feel pretty balanced despite the fact that we expect certainly commodity prices to be higher for next year. And then just put it in perspective, the only comment I made was that this year, our gross margin, as we all know, has really been terrific. We don't expect to see that next year. But right now, we have reasonable visibility. We've got good visibility. Not just on the cost side but on the savings. So we don't provide an inflation number. And we will provide more color on that the next time we get together. But we're pretty pleased with where we are right now.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the productivity savings, you have a number of different programs. And frankly, I don't think you guys ever like give us a summation of it. But when I do it, I think it's approximately about 3% of cost of sales for 2011. Is that about the right number
componenttext: On the productivity savings, you have a number of different programs. And frankly, I don't think you guys ever like give us a summation of it. But when I do it, I think it's approximately about 3% of cost of sales for 2011. Is that about the right number when you add up all the different productivity programs you have going on?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a couple of things, as you mentioned, that are out there. And when we think of continuous improvement it's a year in and year out program. It's not a special program, and that's intended to, I think, it was referred to earlier, is intended to
componenttext: Yes, we have a couple of things, as you mentioned, that are out there. And when we think of continuous improvement it's a year in and year out program. It's not a special program, and that's intended to, I think, it was referred to earlier, is intended to a approximately offset our inflation. The program that we unveiled at CAGNY, which focuses more in non-manufacturing productivity and cost savings to procurement, is separate from that. And it's intended to be, at least in 2011 and '12, 2x the normal productivity. So if we think about our continuous improvement being an attempt to offset inflation. And we think we can do approximately 2x that, you would assume that '11 and '12 has a higher level of productivity. And if you exclude, obviously, next century, which doesn't provide a whole lot of space in 2011, those savings really come in '12, '13.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question is for Dave. Dave, when you talked about international markets, I've always had the expectation that one of the things you can really do to enhance your growth there was to gain some distribution through some acquisition. Can you comment at
componenttext: Last question is for Dave. Dave, when you talked about international markets, I've always had the expectation that one of the things you can really do to enhance your growth there was to gain some distribution through some acquisition. Can you comment at all on the visibility you have on the pipeline of deals that are out there? Some of the companies, like TreeHouse and so forth, they really have some color. They don't comment on timing or where it is because I know that's something you want to keep close to the vest. But can you give us any general parameters? Is it reasonable for us to expect that you will be out there in the acquisition market, trying to add-on to those international franchises that you currently have?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right, I won't give you any additional parameters. I think we've been pretty clear that Latin America and Asian markets are where we're focused. Obviously, we have good cash flows. That's one of the ways we would look to redeploy those cash flows.
componenttext: You're right, I won't give you any additional parameters. I think we've been pretty clear that Latin America and Asian markets are where we're focused. Obviously, we have good cash flows. That's one of the ways we would look to redeploy those cash flows. And we're going to do a disciplined look at what's out there. And beyond that, I wouldn't comment. We continue to be very encouraged by the organic growth of our international businesses in those, in markets around the world. And if you can find something that bolts on and makes sense, we certainly are interested. But I wouldn't give you anything in terms of timing or any of those other things because those things are always so opportunistic.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer, UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer, UBS.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering how you're thinking about the impact to price per volume from innovation? Obviously, we have Drops and Mini's coming. Are you going to be pushing on certain channels, packaging, price point? In addition, I'm guessing there's going to be some
componenttext: I'm wondering how you're thinking about the impact to price per volume from innovation? Obviously, we have Drops and Mini's coming. Are you going to be pushing on certain channels, packaging, price point? In addition, I'm guessing there's going to be some promotion spending upfront that might ease through to 2011. So any color that you can offer about how this might impact your mix in the coming quarters would be great.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about what we did when we look to do the Pieces launch. We have done a very good job. Our sales force executes very well in terms of getting those items to market. We have the Pieces and some of the newer items, but really Pieces
componenttext:
Yes, I think if you think about what we did when we look to do the Pieces launch. We have done a very good job. Our sales force executes very well in terms of getting those items to market. We have the Pieces and some of the newer items, but really Pieces in the first quarter of this year really added almost two points of growth for us into the top line. And that's been more like a point of growth from there on. And when you get to something like Mini's and Drops, they'll build meaningfully volume as you build pipeline here in December and into the first quarter. And then, they'll continue forward. 
In terms of mix, the Reese's Minis and the Hershey's Drops will be in both take-home, stand-up bags, as well as in King Size formats on the front end. So I think from a mix standpoint, probably looks similar to the what the rest of the portfolio would look like, although we are very excited about the ability to get some hand-to-mouth activity on our biggest brands, Hershey and Reese's which we haven't had. So we hope that it will become a very good and consumable item in the convenience and front ends of the stores. I think, as I've said in the third quarter, innovation was additive for some other folks in the category. It came with their bigger brands and did some innovation. Ours happens to come in the fourth quarter and into the early part of next year.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Separately, your net debt, it's dropping to less than one turn of EBITDA. The old Hershey, I think, particularly after a nice move in the stock would show up with a big repurchase of a slug of fresh shares. That seems like 1 million years ago. But my gut
componenttext: Separately, your net debt, it's dropping to less than one turn of EBITDA. The old Hershey, I think, particularly after a nice move in the stock would show up with a big repurchase of a slug of fresh shares. That seems like 1 million years ago. But my gut is, at this point, strategic investments, acquisitions are at the top of the menu. Any comments now that we're getting to these levels on net debt about how you're thinking about investments going forward?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't give any more color than we've already given. I think Dave's is right, M&A is certainly high in our list. And it is opportunistic. We're fortunate to be in a balance sheet situation, where we have those alternatives. And we're looking at all an
componenttext: I wouldn't give any more color than we've already given. I think Dave's is right, M&A is certainly high in our list. And it is opportunistic. We're fortunate to be in a balance sheet situation, where we have those alternatives. And we're looking at all and considering them going forward. So certainly, we want to put our balance sheet to work and, I really wouldn't comment more than that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Serotta, Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Serotta, Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: One area I would want to follow up on was you commented on the sequential improvement in one of your large mass customers. To what do you attribute that improvement? Was it things going on with the customer that we're largely familiar with? Or was it some
componenttext: One area I would want to follow up on was you commented on the sequential improvement in one of your large mass customers. To what do you attribute that improvement? Was it things going on with the customer that we're largely familiar with? Or was it something Hershey specific? And did you actually pick up any incremental display space with that customer?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'd probably rather not comment specifically on anything other than -- as we've gotten into the September, October timeframe in most places, and we get into back-to-school, Halloween, we've done a very nice job of executing in getting into that se
componenttext: I think I'd probably rather not comment specifically on anything other than -- as we've gotten into the September, October timeframe in most places, and we get into back-to-school, Halloween, we've done a very nice job of executing in getting into that season with good merchandising programs. And I think it's across the board with the exception of -- I think in the food class of trade where we didn't get that kind of merchandising in this quarter. But we got it everywhere else. So I think it's really a factor of back-to-school, Halloween and some decent traffic, and I'd leave it at that.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow up on, Bert, your comment on gross margin for 2011. I was a little bit unclear when you said something to the effect that wouldn't be quite as strong as 2010. Were you commenting that gross margin would be directionally down, or tha
componenttext: And then just a follow up on, Bert, your comment on gross margin for 2011. I was a little bit unclear when you said something to the effect that wouldn't be quite as strong as 2010. Were you commenting that gross margin would be directionally down, or that we just wouldn't see the massive gross margin improvement that we saw in 2010?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. We really haven't commented on direction for gross margins. But certainly, what I was trying to imply that you wouldn't expect the type of increases and gains that we've had this year. We'll provide more color as we get a little bit furth
componenttext: It's the latter. We really haven't commented on direction for gross margins. But certainly, what I was trying to imply that you wouldn't expect the type of increases and gains that we've had this year. We'll provide more color as we get a little bit further down in the year in terms of how we see that gross margin.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane, Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane, Bank of America.

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on phasing for next year. Just want to make sure I got a few other things are the Easter, I guess, would be later. So if you could comment on how that will impact just having the Easter season to be longer, is that maybe a positive lift fo
componenttext: Just a question on phasing for next year. Just want to make sure I got a few other things are the Easter, I guess, would be later. So if you could comment on how that will impact just having the Easter season to be longer, is that maybe a positive lift for sales at the second quarter? And then also, in terms of just as raw material increases go through next year, is there anything that we should think about in terms of timing? Is it any more or less of an impact at a certain time of the year? And then also, in terms of the way that you're expecting to manage the flow of cost savings, again, is there anything there that's sort of we should think about on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Hershey Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The comment on Easter, most of the Easter products are, the majority for all intents and purposes shipped in the first quarter. It is a longer Easter season and therefore, you would expect just to probably have more Easter shipments than we would. But the
componenttext:
The comment on Easter, most of the Easter products are, the majority for all intents and purposes shipped in the first quarter. It is a longer Easter season and therefore, you would expect just to probably have more Easter shipments than we would. But then as we've talked about Valentine's and Holiday moving out of the -- Valentine's moving out of the fourth quarter into the first quarter, one of the reasons is because Easter is a little bit later. I think what you would expect, though, is to see it's really anomaly in aberration and takeaway. Because as Easter gets later into April, when you look at first quarter data and first quarter market share, the category might look a little slower than normal because the stuff fills later. Easter is a large component of what happens in that March, April timeframe. So I think market share and takeaway might be more affected by the later Easter. But I think shipments will still fall within the first quarter. 
With respect to productivity, if you remember, we got the last slug of Global Supply Chain Transformation productivity in the first quarter of this year. And then we don't see the Next Century productivity for the fourth quarter of 2011. So those are the two big buckets. Other than that, we are on a standard cost system. So essentially, the cost increases that Bert talked about will get spread largely across the year, based on as volumes flows out. So you kind of come up with an average projected price for yourself on a standard basis and it just flows throughout the year. So for the most part, most of that commodity gets absorbed. But commodity increases, as Bert talked about, will just get absorbed across the year with a couple of caveats around the supply chain stuff.
